componenttextpreview: Yes, we've -- obviously, as you know, we haven't given out the '13 hedging philosophy but -- or our hedging position yet, but we are inclined to see -- generally, we'd like to have about, either on the gas/oil side -- it traditionally takes us about $800
componenttext: Yes, we've -- obviously, as you know, we haven't given out the '13 hedging philosophy but -- or our hedging position yet, but we are inclined to see -- generally, we'd like to have about, either on the gas/oil side -- it traditionally takes us about $800 million a year of CapEx to stay flat on our production, so to the extent we could hedge about half of our gas and traditionally we've done that. Obviously, we're not doing that now. But we like the oil prices we see out there, have seen this year for '13 and '14 -- or for 2013. So I would say that we would be willing to go up to about half hedged on oil at least. Rod, do you want to add to that?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I agree. We continue to see oil as attractive and will continue to look at hedging maybe a little farther out on oil. We're up in touch on liquids. We're about 12% hedged on average for the remainder of this year on liquids, haven't talked about
componenttext: Yes. No, I agree. We continue to see oil as attractive and will continue to look at hedging maybe a little farther out on oil. We're up in touch on liquids. We're about 12% hedged on average for the remainder of this year on liquids, haven't talked about it. But again, it's really difficult to do liquids out much more than a year. But again, I would say looking at 2013, we'd like to be probably more aggressive on the hedging side on the oil and liquids side if we can continue to find attractive prices.

componenttext: Well, those contracts are -- I think, they're about 10 years out. We believe that they're more life at least. componenttext: Yes, I can just add on the ethane side. This is Mike Fiser. The second half of the year does look better than what we saw than first quarter on ethane, in particular. Some of those crackers are back online in the second and third quarter. That will help dramatically. Overall, supply, demand for ethane is fairly balanced through the end of '12. We're adding about 95,000 barrels of petchem [petrochemical] demand, and the fractionation increases are about the same. So we see supply, demand on ethane fairly balanced into the first part of '13. So we're optimistic that we could be under a little better price environment for ethane through balance of the year.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everybody. Welcome to the WPX Energy First Quarter 2012 Operational Update. We appreciate your interest in WPX Energy. Ralph Hill, our CEO; and Rod Sailor, our CFO, will review the prepared slide presentation this morning. Along w
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everybody. Welcome to the WPX Energy First Quarter 2012 Operational Update. We appreciate your interest in WPX Energy. Ralph Hill, our CEO; and Rod Sailor, our CFO, will review the prepared slide presentation this morning. Along with Ralph Hill and Rod Sailor, members of the senior management team, Brian Guderian, Senior VP of Operations; Neal Buck, Senior VP of A&D and Land; and Mike Fiser, Senior VP of Marketing, will be available for questions after the presentation. 
This morning on our website, www.wpxenergy.com, you'll find today's presentation and the press release that was issued earlier today. The 2012 first quarter 10-Q will be filed soon, and you'll be able to access that on the website as well. 
Please review the cautionary language regarding the forward-looking statements on Slide 2 and the disclaimer on the oil and gas reserves on Slide #3. They're important and intrical to our remarks, so please review them. Also included are various non-GAAP numbers that have been reconciled back to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. Those schedules follow the presentation. 
So with that, Ralph, I'll turn it over to you.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David, and welcome to our first quarter 2012 earnings call, and thank you for your interest in WPX Energy. Key takeaways from today's call, when we finish, is to remind everybody we have premier portfolio. We have very strong production growth
componenttext:
Thank you, David, and welcome to our first quarter 2012 earnings call, and thank you for your interest in WPX Energy. Key takeaways from today's call, when we finish, is to remind everybody we have premier portfolio. We have very strong production growth in oil and natural gas liquids. And when the commodity environment is right, we can also do that in natural gas. We have an existing portfolio of 18.5 Tcf of 3P reserves, which gives us the ability to grow all of our product lines in double-digit production for many years. And obviously, currently, we're choosing not to grow our natural gas production. 
We also have tremendous flexibility in our capital budget, and we've responded very quickly to the decade-low natural gas prices by cutting our capital budget over $400 million in February this year. We continue to be a technical and low-cost leader. Our balance sheet is very strong with over $1.8 billion liquidity before our Barnett asset sales proceeds comes in. 
This puts us in a very strong position to separately grow our core areas when the time is right. Currently, the time is right for the Bakken and for the Piceance area, the 2 areas that we see compelling opportunity. And our choice and design, our strategy has been in the best -- to be in the best oil basin in the Bakken, which we are, the best gas and liquid basin in the nation via the Piceance, and we think the best gas station in the nation via the Marcellus. 
So if you turn to Slide 4. Our first 100 days, we became a stand-alone company December 31, as you know. We told the WPX strategy that we're going to be 3 things: first, a disciplined management team; second, that we have a very strong balance sheet; and third, that we have a premier diversified asset base. We've executed on all 3 of these areas in the first 100 days. 
Looking first at the discipline side, in our first month as a separate company, we faced decade-low natural gas prices, which have continued through the first quarter. We merely cut our capital budget by over $400 million and directed over 70% of our capital to oil and liquids-rich plays, which -- and also reaffirmed our commitment to live within our means. 
Second, to further enhance our strong balance sheet, we divested at one of our non-core assets in the Barnett Shale in an accretive transaction for over $306 million. That strengthened our peer leading net debt to EBITDAX ratio from 1.1x to 0.9x, so substantially increased our balance sheet. 
Third, we have focused on our highest return on oil and liquids areas, and we've increased our oil production by 150%. Our liquids production is up 13%, and our oil and liquid revenues are up 45%. Overall this year, we expect 46% of our revenues will come from oil and liquids in 2012, representing about 20% of our volumes, a substantial increase from 2011. 
Looking at Slide 5. For the remainder of 2012, we will adhere to our guiding principles while growing our domestic oil production by 50% to 60%. Our balance sheet will also become stronger after we close the Barnett sale. So remaining priorities for 2012 include: we are a very efficient producer and a very low-cost producer already, but we are seeing cost trends go lower and we expect those to continue, particularly in our gas-prone basins. 
In the Bakken, we expected that all acreage will be held by production by the third quarter. We will also add a sixth rig in July. And by the third quarter, we will have all fit-for-purpose rigs, which are designed specifically for the Bakken. We should begin pad drilling in the third quarter, which should lower our well costs. We haven't done it yet. We're hoping that the well costs will be lower by $500,000 to $1 million. We also will complete our complete final gathering system for oil, water and gas in the third quarter. 
In the Piceance, we will spud our Mancos horizontal test mid-summer to evaluate this potential large gas resource that we already hold by production, and we'll also continue to maximize our liquid recoveries. 
In the Powder River, we are evaluating numerous oil prospects, where we hold over 140,000 acres of deep rights. We expect to begin participating in some of these prospects this year. We also continue to test the Vaca Muerta in Argentina, where we have 250,000 acres exposed to this shale, and we are testing our first well in Columbia. 
And we will be relentless in telling the WPX story of our disciplined management team, superior balance sheet and our premiere diversified asset base to our investors. And we're pleased that we already have 8 sell side analysts covering us, and we expected this number to increase. 
Moving to Slide 6, the Bakken. It's a world-class oil play. It's the best in the nation. We also believe we're located in the best remaining undeveloped reservoir in the Bakken play. We've begun to leverage our service relationships from the Piceance, and we have guarantied completion services now with the dedicated frack crew, pipe delivery, rig moving and we also have fit-for-purpose rigs coming in, as I mentioned. 
Slide 7. In the Middle Bakken activity, we spud 5 wells in the first quarter, 7 wells have been put on sale. You can see those by the color of the green and the blue on the map. All wells -- no, we do not have any wells currently waiting on completion. We also are beginning to delineate our acreage to the south with the wells we drilled in the south piece and they should have mid-June completions. 
Our Three Forks development is also underway. We spud 3 wells in Three Forks, which you can see by the orange color on the map, two of them are north of the lake in what's called the Van Hook area, and one is west of the lake in the Mandaree area. And we expect to have second quarter completion results. 
Our production in March is up to -- was up to 8,700 net barrels a day, an increase of almost 300% over March of 2011, which was about 2,200 net barrels a day. We have 51 completed wells now. We're currently at 5 rigs. And as I mentioned, the sixth rig will come on in July of 2012. And all of our rigs will be fit-for-purpose by the third quarter. We also are converting to multi-well pad drilling in the third quarter -- by third quarter 2012 and the pad could equal up to 3 to 5 laterals on average and possibly more. 
We'd expanded our dedicated frack crew to one complete frack crew. And again, looking at the pad drilling, there's not been a lot of pad drilling on the fields beside partial and sand-ish, but we do think our pad drilling ultimately can save us between maybe $500,000 and $1 million. And those drivers are -- cost drivers are less move days, shared pad construction costs, shared facilities, reduce of drilling days, obviously, moving days, all those things would be playing into lower well costs. 
Slide 8. We continue to be a performance leader on the reservation. This is IHS data, so it's an Mbos-only. You can see that based on -- compared to our competitors, our 180-day rate is superior to our competitors and also results in a higher EUR comparison. On this map -- on this chart, it does 663 Mbos for us. Again, that's not equivalent if we put that in Mboes. IHS only does on Mbos. It would be 721, which is right in -- basically in the middle of our type curve, which 700 to 800 Mboes per well. 
We have 7 wells in this greater than 180 days experience. We continue to outperform our competition. We use the 65%, 35% ceramic sand mix, and we also put on here that some of our competitors are using sand-only. All these wells are Middle Bakken, long laterals only. And again, we believe in the 180-day rate is a much better calculation for EUR. So you can see, our performance continues to be improved and also be better than others on the reservation. 
Slide 9. Part of what we always wanted to do is make sure we bring the efficiencies to adding new base that we're in. The completion of Van Hook gathering system will bring us that. The construction is underway. It's a $34 million investment. We expect to be done by the third quarter of 2012. We'll be able to capture and pipe all of our oil, gas and water and deliver freshwater. Obviously, it won't be flaring gas anymore when this is done. This removes trucking costs and social impacts. It makes us more efficient. 
We think when the system is done, we'll immediately get about a $2 per barrel uptick in savings on our piping -- or our trucking cost. And that will be in the -- by the third quarter of 2012. And by the first quarter 2013, that will be more like a $4 per barrel savings for our oil that's piped out of the Van Hook area. The Arrow system is already up and running. So we'll have 100% of our oil, gas, water,  et cetera will be piped by the time we get done with the Van Hook Gathering System. 
Slide 10. On the netback analysis, we've averaged for the first quarter, we were about 16% discount to $103 WTI price, so a little bit higher discount than we had at -- end of last year. April is slightly higher than that, and we expect May to December to go down as plant turnarounds have come on and other additional capacity. So May through December, we expect to be more like 11% to 12% discount to WTI. 
You can see our current agreements. We have basin sales, and we have what we expect the discount to be on the basin sales for the remainder of the year. We have Manifest Rail. We have Enbridge piping. You can see those on there. We do think we'll have in the future, beginning in 2013, we've been -- pending the final successful negotiations, which we think will happen, we'll have almost 20,000 barrels a day of committed unit train rig capacity in that time frame. We'll be able to receive a Gulf Coast price less associated fees. And we think if you base it on a LSS to WTI spread of $8, we could really be receiving approximately, during that future time, a WTI less $6 to $8. So we feel we've been very proactive. First of all, we've done better than many in the industry, I think, with about a 16% discount in the first quarter. We expect that to be about 11% to 12% in the May through December time frame. And obviously, when we get our unit train rail options go down, we think that would go down even more. So we believe we're taking care of the netback problems that some producers are having in the Bakken. 
Slide 11, Piceance Basin. I just remind you, it's a world-class gas and NGL play for us. Not others have what we have there. Our geologic position is unique. We're the only operator with the scale to be efficient. We've drilled over 4,000 wells there, and we have 10,000 remaining locations. We have a low-cost structure. It's driven by technology, operational efficiency and our enhanced liquids processing, which I'll talk about. And we also have a superior liquid contract, which allows us to get Mont Belvieu pricing when we deliver our barrels to Conway. 
Looking at Slide 12. We spud 70 wells in the first quarter of 2012. We are down to 5 rigs. For 2012, we'll remain at that level. We've got 3 new saltwater disposal wells we will have at this reduced drilling level. Traditionally, we recycle 100% of our water. These new saltwater disposal wells will allow us to continue to do that and keep our costs low. 
Our costs have always been low in the Piceance and 20% of 30% lower than our peers. Last year, in fact, when almost the entire nation and all basins prices went up, our costs were essentially flat because of the efficiencies. And from that base, we still see service costs starting to trend down, lower cementing, perforating, directional drilling type cost. We're also getting -- continue to get better on our frack sizes; our frack-ing; our SIMOPS, which is simultaneous operations; the water handling, I just mentioned. So we continue to be more efficient in the Piceance. 
Slide 13. We had record liquids volumes in the Piceance. For the first time ever, highest we've ever had. They continue to increase in the Valley. I remind you, it yields about 30 barrels per Mcf. In the Ryan Gulch, it's about 58 barrels per MMcf, continued great liquids yields. We have firm cryo capacity, about 770 million a day in the basin. But we actually are flowing over 950 million a day to that because of the interruptible [ph] we have. 
Again, we base flow the Willow Creek facility at 450 million a day. The Meeker facility, we have 200 million of firm, but we deliver sometimes up to 400 million a day there. Echo Springs, we have 120 million a day of firm. And the new Parachute cryo will be coming on in 2014, which will be our next big uptick in our liquids production. So we continue to get more and more liquids productions out of the Piceance. And you can see here in the first quarter of 2012, almost 30,000 barrels a day of net liquids volume. 
Slide 14, Marcellus. It's our final major basin. I'd remind the audience that about 95% of our domestic capital is spent between the Bakken, the Piceance and the Marcellus. We are in the dry gas area of the Marcellus, but it is, we believe, the most prolific area in the Susquehanna County. Again, we like what we've seen in Marcellus. 
We continue to be frustrated that we do not have a lot of long-term data to give you due to the severe delays we have with Laser and the start-up problems that continue with Laser. It is getting better. But the pressures are very erratic, and it's kept us from getting the kind of flows that we would like to have and the kind of data we'd like to have to share with you. We are pleased that our former sister company, Williams/WPZ, closed on this acquisition on February 2012. 
Slide 15. This is where you can see our Piceance model is really starting to take hold in the Marcellus, the same thing I expect to see happen in the Bakken. We have a dedicated frack crew here, fit-for-purpose rigs that are coming in. Our completion cost are 20% lower now due to our efficiencies than they were. 
We have -- our frack efficiencies improved significantly as you can see on this slide. In the first quarter, we were able to pump 224 frack stages with one crew. Last year, in the fourth quarter, with 2 crews, we only pumped 322 frack stages. So we're getting much, much better. We average about 20 days spud-to-rig release in the first quarter 2012, but our record drilling time is now slightly under 14 drilling days. So we're getting much better and our new rigs are coming on, so we believe we'll continue to trend towards the lower end there. 
We've renegotiated our service contracts for the completion side costs, and that's reduced our well cost there by about $400,000 a well. We have many other operational efficiencies coming in, so we hope to eventually be able to lower our well costs by about $1 million per well in the Susquehanna County. 
And looking at the production side, it has -- even with the disappointment in Laser, it has increased about 96% from the fourth quarter 2011 to the first quarter 2012. We're about $53 million a day net in the first quarter, which is up from net $27 million a day in the fourth quarter. Our Susquehanna production rates continue to be high line pressures. 
If you turn to Slide 16, just a little Laser update. Bottom line is, as you know, Williams Partners closed on that deal February 17. We still have pressures as high as 900 pounds we're flowing into. WPZ has indicated it's going to take about 9 months to have field compression operational up there based on what they're putting in. So we're going to be pursuing and have been pursuing temporary wellhead compression until WPZ can get the permanent compression installed. And hopefully, that will continue to get us a little more data exploring our wells and be able to update our type curves in Marcellus. 
Slide 17, Apco. Again, we own 69% interest in Apco. I want to stress a couple of things about Apco. First, it represents less than 5% of our production and reserves and Apco is self-funding, no domestic capital is spent in Apco. Also with all the noise going on in Argentina, I'd like to stress that to our shareholders. But it does represent upside, particularly with the 250,000 net acres we have exposed to the Vaca Muerta Shale and Neuquen Basin. 
Slide 18. Our opinion on the recent Argentine government action that -- I think our opinion and the industry's opinion is that this dispute is between the Argentine government and Repsol, and it's not with the entire energy industry in Argentina. Apco has historically invested the majority of its earnings into exploration and development properties in Argentina, so we do not think it's any target towards Apco or any of the other companies, except there is a dispute between the Argentina government and Repsol. And again, I can't stress enough that we don't send any cash to Argentina. Apco is self-funding, less than 5% of our production and reserves. And we do believe, I think, we have attractive upside in the Vaca Muerta and Columbia. 
Speaking of that, if you look at Slide 19, first quarter operational update. We expect to increase our drilling investments in the Tordillo Formation, which is our traditional formation down there. We'll drill about 33 development wells in Argentina this year. And as you know, we continue to test the Coiron Amargo area for Vaca Muerta and we have 4 tests in the Coiron Amargo this year and one re-frack on the Bajada del Palo area. 
One of the wells is online, the CAS x-1 is -- there's been a press release by our partner. We continue to monitor that well. We intend to have other wells on later this year and the re-frack of the Bajada de Palo will also continue this year. So we'll continue to get more data points, as I mentioned, and understand what we have in Argentina and in the Vaca Muerta, in particular. 
And our first well in Colombia has reached the principal target, the Mirador Formation, and we are testing that well as we speak. And we will spud the second well in that area in the second quarter of 2012. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Rod Sailor for our financial results and 2012 guidance.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ralph. I'll turn you to Slide 21. This morning, we released our first quarter financial results, and I just want to touch on a couple of items. First, as mentioned, we have entered into an agreement to sell our Barnett, Arkoma assets. The numbe
componenttext:
Thank you, Ralph. I'll turn you to Slide 21. This morning, we released our first quarter financial results, and I just want to touch on a couple of items. First, as mentioned, we have entered into an agreement to sell our Barnett, Arkoma assets. The numbers represented both in our release and here have been adjusted to reflect the impact of that sale. 
The company's overall domestic, international production climbed 11% 1Q 2012 versus 1Q 2011, with average daily production of 1.4 Bcfe per day. For the quarter, that's slightly ahead of our expectations. Domestic gas was driven largely by increases in the Piceance and the Marcellus basins. Even with capital spending reductions, which -- that took effect late in the first quarter, we expect the Piceance production to continue to grow into the second quarter. We expect volumes to continue to rise in Marcellus as gas comes on from wells behind pipe and continued activity in Susquehanna County. Unfortunately, decade-low gas prices have impacted our gas revenues as realized prices are almost $1 lower first quarter 2012 versus first quarter 2011. 
Good news, oil -- total oil production is up 46% first quarter this year over first quarter last year. Our domestic oil production increases are driven by activities in our highest returning basin, the Bakken, whereas Ralph mentioned, we continue to be pleased with our well results. Oil production in the Bakken is up over 300%. We have seen basis differentials widen in the first quarter but -- and lower realized prices, but they were somewhat helped by higher oil prices in general. And as Ralph mentioned, we're taking steps to minimize basin differentials in the Bakken going forward. 
NGL productions was up 1Q 2012 versus 1Q 2011 as we continue to process more volumes, primarily in the Piceance basin. Quarter-over-quarter comparisons were helped somewhat by planned outages experienced in late first quarter 2011 on the fact that we're utilizing more firm interruptible capacity in first quarter 2012. Unfortunately, we continue to see a weakening in the price for composite barrel, which has impacted our realized prices in the first quarter of 2012.
As mentioned in our release, we have been experienced impairments totaling $52 million in the first quarter. Absent these impairments, our adjusted net loss from continuing operations would have been $9 million versus adjusted net income of $5 million in the first quarter 2011. Our adjusted EBITDAX totaled $262 million in the first quarter. Despite the realized gas prices being down approximately 20% lower than first quarter 2011, adjusted EBITDAX was only down approximately 6%, largely due to total production increases, especially higher volumes of oil and natural gas and hedges in place. 
At the bottom of Slide 21, again, total capital spending was $428 million for the first quarter. We announced our capital cuts in February. They started taking effect later in the first quarter. So on a go-forward basis, we do expect to see a continuing decrease for the remaining quarters in 2012. 
If I might turn you to Slide 22. We are adjusting our production and EBITDAX guidance to reflect the impact of the sale of our assets in the Barnett and Arkoma basins. This adjustment reduces our gas production to 1.09 Bcfe per day. It has no impact on our oil or natural gas liquids. EBITDAX guidance has been reduced by about $25 million to account for the loss of cash flow from the sale of our Barnett and Arkoma properties. 
And then down the middle of the page there, you can see no change for projected capital spending of $1.2 billion. We have broken out oil and NGLs on our rule of thumb metric to help in calculating price changes.
Finally, if I might turn you to Slide 23. Ralph just touched on this, but we have put a liquidity slide in the presentation. Good news is we have over $1.8 billion of liquidity. We expect to have no borrowings under our revolver at year end, and we expect to have the remainder of Arkoma and Barnett asset sale proceeds of approximately $75 million received here shortly. 
So before I turn it back over to Ralph, I'd just like to say, with strong production, continue to have a strong balance sheet and a low debt-to-EBITDA ratio. 
With that, I'll turn it back to Ralph.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rod. I'll sum it up with basically our premier portfolio. We have 18.5 Tcf of 3P reserves. Very strong balance sheet, as you can see our shift to oil [indiscernible] continues in the Bakken and the Piceance liquids recoveries. We are the #1 pro
componenttext:
Thank you, Rod. I'll sum it up with basically our premier portfolio. We have 18.5 Tcf of 3P reserves. Very strong balance sheet, as you can see our shift to oil [indiscernible] continues in the Bakken and the Piceance liquids recoveries. We are the #1 producer in Colorado. We are taking those efficiencies into the Bakken and the Marcellus. We expect to get better and better. We're very flexible on our capital budget as you've seen before. 
We're go to be very -- continue to have a strong balance sheet, which will be enhanced by the proceeds from the Barnett sale. And we like our 3 basins. We think those are the 3 best basis in the country. We like our financial strength. We're set up to survive very easily in this environment and to thrive as environment turns around. In the meantime, we'll continue to grow oil and liquids productions. 
So we feel very good about what we are. It's been a great -- I want to complement our employees on their first 100 days, how well they did and how everything has just come together very smoothly, and we're proud to have the opportunity to represent our WPX employees. 
With that, that's the end of prepared remarks. Dave?

componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions for me. Just trying to understand a little bit better your NGL realizations in the quarter and, specifically, if you could help us on the revenue deduct line, which was running about $10 per barrel, if you have any color on that.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, as we have talked about, we did renegotiate those contracts in 2011. On the processing side, we run about -- I think it's about $0.36. But then we also share proceeds of, I think, about 70% to 30%. So we are -- it's kind of percent of proceeds
componenttext: Yes. Again, as we have talked about, we did renegotiate those contracts in 2011. On the processing side, we run about -- I think it's about $0.36. But then we also share proceeds of, I think, about 70% to 30%. So we are -- it's kind of percent of proceeds for the remainder. So I think -- so just -- I mean, when we put our plan and our guidance together, we were expecting to see a composite barrel of about $51 less about, I think, $6 deducts, $7 deducts to about $43 -- $45 -- sorry, $43. What we're seeing is a $43 composite barrel and a realized price of about $33 -- $33.15.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just in terms of, I guess, follow-on to that question. Could you talk about, I guess, the impact on your Piceance economics and does this change your view, I guess, heading into the back half of the year into 2013, if realizations continue
componenttext: Great. And then just in terms of, I guess, follow-on to that question. Could you talk about, I guess, the impact on your Piceance economics and does this change your view, I guess, heading into the back half of the year into 2013, if realizations continue to remain kind of at these levels?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, actually -- this is Ralph. Our actual -- with the low gas prices -- well, the short answer is, no, it doesn't change it. We still are getting a nice uplift in the Piceance. We feel very comfortable with the 5 rigs we have operating there. And one of
componenttext: Well, actually -- this is Ralph. Our actual -- with the low gas prices -- well, the short answer is, no, it doesn't change it. We still are getting a nice uplift in the Piceance. We feel very comfortable with the 5 rigs we have operating there. And one of those is in the Ryan Gulch area, which is getting even more of an uplift, and it's more like 58 barrels per million. So we feel comfortable where we are with those 5 rigs [indiscernible].

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say while we're -- while we're all realizing less on our NGLs, the uplift is -- we still get a nice uplift because, again, the fuel and shrink piece is on the gas is so low. So we continue to meet our hurdle requirements in the Piceance even
componenttext: Yes, I would say while we're -- while we're all realizing less on our NGLs, the uplift is -- we still get a nice uplift because, again, the fuel and shrink piece is on the gas is so low. So we continue to meet our hurdle requirements in the Piceance even with the lower NGL realizations.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just final question for me on the international side. In Colombia, would you be able to provide I guess the -- have you logged that well and would you be able to provide, I guess, the net pay that you saw in the Mirador? And then within th
componenttext: Great. And then just final question for me on the international side. In Colombia, would you be able to provide I guess the -- have you logged that well and would you be able to provide, I guess, the net pay that you saw in the Mirador? And then within that context, thinking about Apco, as you mentioned, really WPX is not committing any capital to Apco. Is this is an asset that you can potentially spin out over time to shareholders?

componenttext: We will continue to understand our position in the Vaca Muerta, get some good data points this year and early next year, as we mentioned. And then we will take the appropriate actions when we can to make sure we maximize the value of Apco for our shareholders.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can you talk to us, is there any effort to add acreage outside of your 3 main areas in pursuing other forward-looking oil or liquids-focused projects?
componenttext: Can you talk to us, is there any effort to add acreage outside of your 3 main areas in pursuing other forward-looking oil or liquids-focused projects?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: We are very active looking in many areas. We always have been. Again, to do something, it's going to have to be very compelling. One of the areas I've mentioned many times on the road and in conferences that makes a lot of sense for us in addition to the
componenttext: We are very active looking in many areas. We always have been. Again, to do something, it's going to have to be very compelling. One of the areas I've mentioned many times on the road and in conferences that makes a lot of sense for us in addition to the current basin of the Bakken, if we could add there, is the wet window in the Utica shale. We think that would be a natural fit for our Marcellus team. We wouldn't have to add a new asset team. We could take our rigs and our dedicated completion crews interchangeably to the Utica from the Marcellus. In fact, the drilling and where they join in the Utica Shale right now is actually closer to our Canonsburg office than our Susquehanna drilling. So that's a natural fit for us. So we continue to look at that area. We understand it geologically. We think there are a number players there that might have more than that they can say grace over, that we might have an opportunity to maybe do some drill-to-earns with, and also some other producers that have not really -- not built to do large-scale efficiency type drilling like we do. So we might be able to get some opportunities that way. So that's an area that continues to have attraction to us. Again, it would have to be compelling to do anything there. And we also are -- I would say, the other major oil plays that you see in the nation, our technical team continues to scour, and our A&D and Land look at those. We have a good understanding of that. And if there was something compelling come along, we could also look at another basin.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as you look at the end of the year, your focused shifting towards oil, to anticipate some oil reserve adds, how do you guys think about proved undeveloped gas reserves and the potential revisions downward because of lower prices? Is it some
componenttext: Okay. And then as you look at the end of the year, your focused shifting towards oil, to anticipate some oil reserve adds, how do you guys think about proved undeveloped gas reserves and the potential revisions downward because of lower prices? Is it something you're already looking at?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, most of our portfolio has been very strong to low gas prices for many years. The one thing that we'll -- I think we'll have to look the most at is the 5-year rule in the large unconventional areas because it's really based on what your drilling prog
componenttext: Well, most of our portfolio has been very strong to low gas prices for many years. The one thing that we'll -- I think we'll have to look the most at is the 5-year rule in the large unconventional areas because it's really based on what your drilling program will be going forward. So those reserves don't really go away. But as you know, under the 5-year rule, take them off for a year and you add them for a year. So I would say that's one area that we will have a strong focus on. And I'm not saying anything is going to happen there, but that's traditionally what we'll have to look at. Neal, would you like to add anything to the reserve side?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I agree, Ralph. We have to demonstrate our plan to -- how much of these reserves to drill in the next 5 years will determine what's proved. But we also -- we always published our probable and possible reserves so they can have some movement back
componenttext: Yes. No, I agree, Ralph. We have to demonstrate our plan to -- how much of these reserves to drill in the next 5 years will determine what's proved. But we also -- we always published our probable and possible reserves so they can have some movement back and forth between the 2. And on the price case, the SEC encourages you to do alternate price scenarios as well. So typically, we'll do a case that's representative of what current prices are forward prices as well. So as Ralph said, I think a lot of that is just the technicalities of how you calculate under SEC rules. But we're not seeing anything that's a revision due to such things as poorer performance than expected or higher capital costs than expected.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: All right, great. And kind of a follow-up. I know you gave some detail already on the renegotiated processing. But in passing, it was mentioned that you're getting Mont Belvieu type prices at Conway. What specific production does get Conway prices or is i
componenttext: All right, great. And kind of a follow-up. I know you gave some detail already on the renegotiated processing. But in passing, it was mentioned that you're getting Mont Belvieu type prices at Conway. What specific production does get Conway prices or is it that the whole thing has been improved through your good renegotiations?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012

componenttext: It's all Belvieu, but I'll give this to Mike Fisher.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think an important point on this is regarding our NGL position. We like to reemphasize this is that all of our product reaches Mont Belvieu. We're not exposed to large price differentials currently being experienced at Conway. So effectively, all o
componenttext: Yes, I think an important point on this is regarding our NGL position. We like to reemphasize this is that all of our product reaches Mont Belvieu. We're not exposed to large price differentials currently being experienced at Conway. So effectively, all of our products, either through Overland Pass Pipeline or Mid-American Pipeline, reaches Mont Belvieu.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Brian Velie with Capital One Southcoast.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Brian Velie with Capital One Southcoast.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Couple of quick questions in the Bakken. There was a question earlier about possible acquisitions elsewhere outside of your 3 main focus areas right now. I wanted to kind of drill in a little bit on the Bakken side of things. Are there many opportunities?
componenttext: Couple of quick questions in the Bakken. There was a question earlier about possible acquisitions elsewhere outside of your 3 main focus areas right now. I wanted to kind of drill in a little bit on the Bakken side of things. Are there many opportunities? Are you exploring any or seeing any opportunities to add significant pieces of acreage there in the Bakken for yourselves or is your, I guess, exploratory stuff going on in other places like the Utica?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: There are opportunities in the Bakken. I think people know we're interested. Again, we like what we have, approximately 90,000 acres. We have a lot of drilling ahead of us. We're gaining a lot of efficiencies. But we've made it known that we're interested
componenttext: There are opportunities in the Bakken. I think people know we're interested. Again, we like what we have, approximately 90,000 acres. We have a lot of drilling ahead of us. We're gaining a lot of efficiencies. But we've made it known that we're interested in the Bakken. We continue to like the Bakken, so there are opportunities in the Bakken. That's all I can say. Again, we do have a strong balance sheet, but we also are going to be very disciplined. So it'd have to be very compelling for us, but our deal team continuous to see opportunities.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can you add any color on those opportunities? What would you say -- especially in your area there near and around the reservation, is there kind of going rate for acreage costs in that portion of the Bakken?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: I mean, it seems to be all over the map right now, so not really. And I really can't add a lot more color. You're seeing some other deals that are published out there. You know what our original deal was. We like that deal, so that appears to be what some
componenttext: I mean, it seems to be all over the map right now, so not really. And I really can't add a lot more color. You're seeing some other deals that are published out there. You know what our original deal was. We like that deal, so that appears to be what some other acreage is going for. But I'm not predicting we're going to be at that level or anything like that. It's just that, I think, there's some areas just both on and off the reservations that are attractive to us. And all we can say is that we're interested, but we're not going to go jump out there and do anything that would strain our balance sheet.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012

componenttext: Okay, great. And then finally, in Bakken, you mentioned some cost improvements that you're seeing by leveraging all the work that you've done in the Piceance. Is there any change to maybe what our well cost assumptions should be right now or do you see a point in time, maybe it's the start of 2013, where those higher prices that we saw last quarter start to come down?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's still going to take some time. We're changing the whole fleet out, as we mentioned, by the third quarter. So that takes some time to get that done with the new rigs. We will move to pad drilling, and we hope to have those kinds of saving
componenttext: Yes, I think it's still going to take some time. We're changing the whole fleet out, as we mentioned, by the third quarter. So that takes some time to get that done with the new rigs. We will move to pad drilling, and we hope to have those kinds of savings. That's why we're going to pad drilling, but that's late third quarter. So I think that's really more of a look at 2013, maybe late 2012.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: I just had 2 quick questions. The first is how are you looking as far as inventory on Bakken permits and what are your expectations for that going forward, whether you can build inventory of permits or not? And then second, what is the incremental expecte
componenttext: I just had 2 quick questions. The first is how are you looking as far as inventory on Bakken permits and what are your expectations for that going forward, whether you can build inventory of permits or not? And then second, what is the incremental expected return that you anticipate from adding those ceramics to your completions in the Bakken?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Bryan. I'll take at least the first part of this. We continue to work aggressively on the permitting front. I think we are encouraged that some resources are being added on the regulatory side to better prosecute things in a timely fashion. We rep
componenttext: This is Bryan. I'll take at least the first part of this. We continue to work aggressively on the permitting front. I think we are encouraged that some resources are being added on the regulatory side to better prosecute things in a timely fashion. We reported last quarter that at least the prerequisite work that we're required to accomplish upfront, that is largely done for all of our pads. So what we're required to submit to initiate that permitting process has been completed on our side, very pleased with the effort around that over the past year. The logjam, of course, is over on the regulatory side. I think the good news is whenever we've had been in the pinch a little bit, we've been able to accelerate some things through that process, and so we have not had any idle time to date. We certainly would like to see that sieve open up a little bit. Currently, we've got about 2 -- I think 2 permits in front of each rig and so, perhaps, 60 to 90 days worth of lead time. Those aren't always the permits that you would like to have. But nonetheless, we've been able to stay out in front and avoid any standby time. We are expecting some breakthroughs very shortly just based on dialogues that we've had with the regulators there, the tribal involvement of late and the request, frankly, all the way to Secretary Salazar for additional resources to be plugged in to the process. So the short answer is, it's adequate but it could be better. We're doing okay though.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: And on the ceramic, I think, I appreciate that question. Using 65%, 35% ceramic sand mix adds about $1 million to our well cost versus the pure sand only. But if you just look at our chart that's on Slide 8, if you look at the best sand player that's on t
componenttext: And on the ceramic, I think, I appreciate that question. Using 65%, 35% ceramic sand mix adds about $1 million to our well cost versus the pure sand only. But if you just look at our chart that's on Slide 8, if you look at the best sand player that's on the reservation that we've compared to our reserves, we're 29% higher than and their reserves. If you look at worst, we're 94% better than a pure sand player. We also believe and it's our belief, and others may not believe this, that if you sand-only, that you're -- ultimately, the sand will get crushed and you have a lot more work-over costs and you ultimately spend more money on your well along down the life of the well versus the ceramics. So we're firmly convinced the 65%, 35% works. And our data shows that we're anywhere from 30% to 94% better than pure sand.

On the HBP issues, you mentioned the Bakken is going to be done basically by the third quarter. Can you remind us where the Marcellus stands and is there anything else outstanding?

componenttext: The Marcellus is the only other place that's outstanding. With the 3 rigs operating, we will -- we could be in Susquehanna, have our production held by within about 18 to 24 months. Bryan, is that about right?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: And if we -- here's another way to look at it. If we did no drilling in Susquehanna, Westmoreland or Clearfield or Centre counties, over the next couple of years, meaning '13 and '14, we would -- we have the ability to -- if we wanted to, we could spend a
componenttext: And if we -- here's another way to look at it. If we did no drilling in Susquehanna, Westmoreland or Clearfield or Centre counties, over the next couple of years, meaning '13 and '14, we would -- we have the ability to -- if we wanted to, we could spend about $50 or so million could renew all of our leases based on the automatic kickers and things we have in there. So that would be the maximum exposure we have. And I would assume we didn't drill at all from now on. So we'll get it done within 12 to 18 months. And if prices were really poor, continue to be very, very poor, we could move those rigs and do other things and actually just renew our leases. And we like the areas. We would probably do that. But at this point, just on the drilling schedule, within 18 months or so.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've -- obviously, as you know, we haven't given out the '13 hedging philosophy but -- or our hedging position yet, but we are inclined to see -- generally, we'd like to have about, either on the gas/oil side -- it traditionally takes us about $800
componenttext: Yes, we've -- obviously, as you know, we haven't given out the '13 hedging philosophy but -- or our hedging position yet, but we are inclined to see -- generally, we'd like to have about, either on the gas/oil side -- it traditionally takes us about $800 million a year of CapEx to stay flat on our production, so to the extent we could hedge about half of our gas and traditionally we've done that. Obviously, we're not doing that now. But we like the oil prices we see out there, have seen this year for '13 and '14 -- or for 2013. So I would say that we would be willing to go up to about half hedged on oil at least. Rod, do you want to add to that?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I agree. We continue to see oil as attractive and will continue to look at hedging maybe a little farther out on oil. We're up in a touch on liquids. We're about 12% hedged on average for the remainder of this year on liquids, haven't talked abou
componenttext: Yes. No, I agree. We continue to see oil as attractive and will continue to look at hedging maybe a little farther out on oil. We're up in a touch on liquids. We're about 12% hedged on average for the remainder of this year on liquids, haven't talked about it. But again, it's really difficult to do liquids out much more than a year. But again, I would say looking at 2013, we'd like to be probably more aggressive on the hedging side on the oil and liquids side if we can continue to find attractive prices.

componenttext: Well, those contracts are -- I think, they're about 10 years out. We believe that they're more life at least. What I neglected to add is, again, we think we will see some price improvement under those contracts in 2013. The fee will go from $0.36 to $0.07. We will -- or we will have a revenue sharing agreement at 50-50 on margin up to $0.34. And then after anything over $0.34, we will keep 80% of the margins. So I would say our composite barrel right now is about 60% ethane and 19% propane. We've seen those prices significantly weaken from the fourth quarter of last year. That's impacting it. And then again, we'll see some fee improvement in 2013 as these -- the impact of these renegotiated contracts come into play.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I can just add on the ethane side. This is Mike Fiser. The second half of the year does look better than what we saw than first quarter on ethane, in particular. Some of those crackers are back online in the second and third quarter. That will help d
componenttext: Yes, I can just add on the ethane side. This is Mike Fiser. The second half of the year does look better than what we saw than first quarter on ethane, in particular. Some of those crackers are back online in the second and third quarter. That will help dramatically. Overall, supply, demand for ethane is fairly balanced through the end of '12. We're adding about 95,000 barrels of petchem [petrochemical] demand, and the fractionation increases are about the same. So we see supply, demand on ethane fairly balanced into the first part of '13. So we're optimistic that we could be under a little better price environment for ethane through balance of the year.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everybody. Welcome to the WPX Energy First Quarter 2012 Operational Update. We appreciate your interest in WPX Energy. Ralph Hill, our CEO; and Rod Sailor, our CFO, will review the prepared slide presentation this morning. Along w
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everybody. Welcome to the WPX Energy First Quarter 2012 Operational Update. We appreciate your interest in WPX Energy. Ralph Hill, our CEO; and Rod Sailor, our CFO, will review the prepared slide presentation this morning. Along with Ralph Hill and Rod Sailor, members of the senior management team, Brian Guderian, Senior VP of Operations; Neal Buck, Senior VP of A&D and Land; and Mike Fiser, Senior VP of Marketing, will be available for questions after the presentation. 
This morning on our website, www.wpxenergy.com, you'll find today's presentation and the press release that was issued earlier today. The 2012 first quarter 10-Q will be filed soon, and you'll be able to access that on the website as well. 
Please review the cautionary language regarding the forward-looking statements on Slide 2 and the disclaimer on the oil and gas reserves on Slide #3. They're important and intrical to our remarks, so please review them. Also included are various non-GAAP numbers that have been reconciled back to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. Those schedules follow the presentation. 
So with that, Ralph, I'll turn it over to you.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David, and welcome to our first quarter 2012 earnings call, and thank you for your interest in WPX Energy. Key takeaways from today's call, when we finish, is to remind everybody we have premier portfolio. We have very strong production growth
componenttext:
Thank you, David, and welcome to our first quarter 2012 earnings call, and thank you for your interest in WPX Energy. Key takeaways from today's call, when we finish, is to remind everybody we have premier portfolio. We have very strong production growth in oil and natural gas liquids. And when the commodity environment is right, we can also do that in natural gas. We have an existing portfolio of 18.5 Tcf of 3P reserves, which gives us the ability to grow all of our product lines in double-digit production for many years. And obviously, currently, we're choosing not to grow our natural gas production. 
We also have tremendous flexibility in our capital budget, and we've responded very quickly to the decade-low natural gas prices by cutting our capital budget over $400 million in February this year. We continue to be a technical and low-cost leader. Our balance sheet is very strong with over $1.8 billion liquidity before our Barnett asset sales proceeds comes in. 
This puts us in a very strong position to separately grow our core areas when the time is right. Currently, the time is right for the Bakken and for the Piceance area, the 2 areas that we see compelling opportunity. And our choice and design, our strategy has been in the best -- to be in the best oil basin in the Bakken, which we are, the best gas and liquid basin in the nation via the Piceance, and we think the best gas station in the nation via the Marcellus. 
So if you turn to Slide 4. Our first 100 days, we became a stand-alone company December 31, as you know. We told the WPX strategy that we're going to be 3 things: first, a disciplined management team; second, that we have a very strong balance sheet; and third, that we have a premier diversified asset base. We've executed on all 3 of these areas in the first 100 days. 
Looking first at the discipline side, in our first month as a separate company, we faced decade-low natural gas prices, which have continued through the first quarter. We merely cut our capital budget by over $400 million and directed over 70% of our capital to oil and liquids-rich plays, which -- and also reaffirmed our commitment to live within our means. 
Second, to further enhance our strong balance sheet, we divested at one of our non-core assets in the Barnett Shale in an accretive transaction for over $306 million. That strengthened our peer leading net debt to EBITDAX ratio from 1.1x to 0.9x, so substantially increased our balance sheet. 
Third, we have focused on our highest return on oil and liquids areas, and we've increased our oil production by 150%. Our liquids production is up 13%, and our oil and liquid revenues are up 45%. Overall this year, we expect 46% of our revenues will come from oil and liquids in 2012, representing about 20% of our volumes, a substantial increase from 2011. 
Looking at Slide 5. For the remainder of 2012, we will adhere to our guiding principles while growing our domestic oil production by 50% to 60%. Our balance sheet will also become stronger after we close the Barnett sale. So remaining priorities for 2012 include: we are a very efficient producer and a very low-cost producer already, but we are seeing cost trends go lower and we expect those to continue, particularly in our gas-prone basins. 
In the Bakken, we expected that all acreage will be held by production by the third quarter. We will also add a sixth rig in July. And by the third quarter, we will have all fit-for-purpose rigs, which are designed specifically for the Bakken. We should begin pad drilling in the third quarter, which should lower our well costs. We haven't done it yet. We're hoping that the well costs will be lower by $500,000 to $1 million. We also will complete our complete final gathering system for oil, water and gas in the third quarter. 
In the Piceance, we will spud our Mancos horizontal test mid-summer to evaluate this potential large gas resource that we already hold by production, and we'll also continue to maximize our liquid recoveries. 
In the Powder River, we are evaluating numerous oil prospects, where we hold over 140,000 acres of deep rights. We expect to begin participating in some of these prospects this year. We also continue to test the Vaca Muerta in Argentina, where we have 250,000 acres exposed to this shale, and we are testing our first well in Columbia. 
And we will be relentless in telling the WPX story of our disciplined management team, superior balance sheet and our premiere diversified asset base to our investors. And we're pleased that we already have 8 sell side analysts covering us, and we expected this number to increase. 
Moving to Slide 6, the Bakken. It's a world-class oil play. It's the best in the nation. We also believe we're located in the best remaining undeveloped reservoir in the Bakken play. We've begun to leverage our service relationships from the Piceance, and we have guaranteed completion services now with the dedicated frac crew, pipe delivery, rig moving and we also have fit-for-purpose rigs coming in, as I mentioned. 
Slide 7. In the Middle Bakken activity, we spud 5 wells in the first quarter, 7 wells have been put on sale. You can see those by the color of the green and the blue on the map. All wells -- no, we do not have any wells currently waiting on completion. We also are beginning to delineate our acreage to the south with the wells we drilled in the south piece and they should have mid-June completions. 
Our Three Forks development is also underway. We spud 3 wells in Three Forks, which you can see by the orange color on the map, two of them are north of the lake in what's called the Van Hook area, and one is west of the lake in the Mandaree area. And we expect to have second quarter completion results. 
Our production in March is up to -- was up to 8,700 net barrels a day, an increase of almost 300% over March of 2011, which was about 2,200 net barrels a day. We have 51 completed wells now. We're currently at 5 rigs. And as I mentioned, the sixth rig will come on in July of 2012. And all of our rigs will be fit-for-purpose by the third quarter. We also are converting to multi-well pad drilling in the third quarter -- by third quarter 2012 and the pad could equal up to 3 to 5 laterals on average and possibly more. 
We'd expanded our dedicated frac crew to one complete frac crew. And again, looking at the pad drilling, there's not been a lot of pad drilling on the fields beside partial and sand-ish, but we do think our pad drilling ultimately can save us between maybe $500,000 and $1 million. And those drivers are -- cost drivers are less move days, shared pad construction costs, shared facilities, reduce of drilling days, obviously, moving days, all those things would be playing into lower well costs. 
Slide 8. We continue to be a performance leader on the reservation. This is IHS data, so it's an Mbos-only. You can see that based on -- compared to our competitors, our 180-day rate is superior to our competitors and also results in a higher EUR comparison. On this map -- on this chart, it does 663 Mbos for us. Again, that's not equivalent if we put that in Mboes. IHS only does on Mbos. It would be 721, which is right in -- basically in the middle of our type curve, which 700 to 800 Mboes per well. 
We have 7 wells in this greater than 180 days experience. We continue to outperform our competition. We use the 65%, 35% ceramic sand mix, and we also put on here that some of our competitors are using sand-only. All these wells are Middle Bakken, long laterals only. And again, we believe in the 180-day rate is a much better calculation for EUR. So you can see, our performance continues to be improved and also be better than others on the reservation. 
Slide 9. Part of what we always wanted to do is make sure we bring the efficiencies to adding new base that we're in. The completion of Van Hook gathering system will bring us that. The construction is underway. It's a $34 million investment. We expect to be done by the third quarter of 2012. We'll be able to capture and pipe all of our oil, gas and water and deliver freshwater. Obviously, it won't be flaring gas anymore when this is done. This removes trucking costs and social impacts. It makes us more efficient. 
We think when the system is done, we'll immediately get about a $2 per barrel uptick in savings on our piping -- or our trucking cost. And that will be in the -- by the third quarter of 2012. And by the first quarter 2013, that will be more like a $4 per barrel savings for our oil that's piped out of the Van Hook area. The Arrow system is already up and running. So we'll have 100% of our oil, gas, water,  et cetera will be piped by the time we get done with the Van Hook Gathering System. 
Slide 10. On the netback analysis, we've averaged for the first quarter, we were about 16% discount to $103 WTI price, so a little bit higher discount than we had at -- end of last year. April is slightly higher than that, and we expect May to December to go down as plant turnarounds have come on and other additional capacity. So May through December, we expect to be more like 11% to 12% discount to WTI. 
You can see our current agreements. We have basin sales, and we have what we expect the discount to be on the basin sales for the remainder of the year. We have Manifest Rail. We have Enbridge piping. You can see those on there. We do think we'll have in the future, beginning in 2013, we've been -- pending the final successful negotiations, which we think will happen, we'll have almost 20,000 barrels a day of committed unit train rig capacity in that time frame. We'll be able to receive a Gulf Coast price less associated fees. And we think if you base it on a LSS to WTI spread of $8, we could really be receiving approximately, during that future time, a WTI less $6 to $8. So we feel we've been very proactive. First of all, we've done better than many in the industry, I think, with about a 16% discount in the first quarter. We expect that to be about 11% to 12% in the May through December time frame. And obviously, when we get our unit train rail options go down, we think that would go down even more. So we believe we're taking care of the netback problems that some producers are having in the Bakken. 
Slide 11, Piceance Basin. I just remind you, it's a world-class gas and NGL play for us. Not others have what we have there. Our geologic position is unique. We're the only operator with the scale to be efficient. We've drilled over 4,000 wells there, and we have 10,000 remaining locations. We have a low-cost structure. It's driven by technology, operational efficiency and our enhanced liquids processing, which I'll talk about. And we also have a superior liquid contract, which allows us to get Mont Belvieu pricing when we deliver our barrels to Conway. 
Looking at Slide 12. We spud 70 wells in the first quarter of 2012. We are down to 5 rigs. For 2012, we'll remain at that level. We've got 3 new saltwater disposal wells we will have at this reduced drilling level. Traditionally, we recycle 100% of our water. These new saltwater disposal wells will allow us to continue to do that and keep our costs low. 
Our costs have always been low in the Piceance and 20% of 30% lower than our peers. Last year, in fact, when almost the entire nation and all basins prices went up, our costs were essentially flat because of the efficiencies. And from that base, we still see service costs starting to trend down, lower cementing, perforating, directional drilling type cost. We're also getting -- continue to get better on our frac sizes; our frac-ing; our SIMOPS, which is simultaneous operations; the water handling, I just mentioned. So we continue to be more efficient in the Piceance. 
Slide 13. We had record liquids volumes in the Piceance. For the first time ever, highest we've ever had. They continue to increase in the Valley. I remind you, it yields about 30 barrels per Mcf. In the Ryan Gulch, it's about 58 barrels per MMcf, continued great liquids yields. We have firm cryo capacity, about 770 million a day in the basin. But we actually are flowing over 950 million a day to that because of the interruptible [ph] we have. 
Again, we base flow the Willow Creek facility at 450 million a day. The Meeker facility, we have 200 million of firm, but we deliver sometimes up to 400 million a day there. Echo Springs, we have 120 million a day of firm. And the new Parachute cryo will be coming on in 2014, which will be our next big uptick in our liquids production. So we continue to get more and more liquids productions out of the Piceance. And you can see here in the first quarter of 2012, almost 30,000 barrels a day of net liquids volume. 
Slide 14, Marcellus. It's our final major basin. I'd remind the audience that about 95% of our domestic capital is spent between the Bakken, the Piceance and the Marcellus. We are in the dry gas area of the Marcellus, but it is, we believe, the most prolific area in the Susquehanna County. Again, we like what we've seen in Marcellus. 
We continue to be frustrated that we do not have a lot of long-term data to give you due to the severe delays we have with Laser and the start-up problems that continue with Laser. It is getting better. But the pressures are very erratic, and it's kept us from getting the kind of flows that we would like to have and the kind of data we'd like to have to share with you. We are pleased that our former sister company, Williams/WPZ, closed on this acquisition on February 2012. 
Slide 15. This is where you can see our Piceance model is really starting to take hold in the Marcellus, the same thing I expect to see happen in the Bakken. We have a dedicated frac crew here, fit-for-purpose rigs that are coming in. Our completion cost are 20% lower now due to our efficiencies than they were. 
We have -- our frac efficiencies improved significantly as you can see on this slide. In the first quarter, we were able to pump 224 frac stages with one crew. Last year, in the fourth quarter, with 2 crews, we only pumped 322 frac stages. So we're getting much, much better. We average about 20 days spud-to-rig release in the first quarter 2012, but our record drilling time is now slightly under 14 drilling days. So we're getting much better and our new rigs are coming on, so we believe we'll continue to trend towards the lower end there. 
We've renegotiated our service contracts for the completion side costs, and that's reduced our well cost there by about $400,000 a well. We have many other operational efficiencies coming in, so we hope to eventually be able to lower our well costs by about $1 million per well in the Susquehanna County. 
And looking at the production side, it has -- even with the disappointment in Laser, it has increased about 96% from the fourth quarter 2011 to the first quarter 2012. We're about $53 million a day net in the first quarter, which is up from net $27 million a day in the fourth quarter. Our Susquehanna production rates continue to be high line pressures. 
If you turn to Slide 16, just a little Laser update. Bottom line is, as you know, Williams Partners closed on that deal February 17. We still have pressures as high as 900 pounds we're flowing into. WPZ has indicated it's going to take about 9 months to have field compression operational up there based on what they're putting in. So we're going to be pursuing and have been pursuing temporary wellhead compression until WPZ can get the permanent compression installed. And hopefully, that will continue to get us a little more data exploring our wells and be able to update our type curves in Marcellus. 
Slide 17, Apco. Again, we own 69% interest in Apco. I want to stress a couple of things about Apco. First, it represents less than 5% of our production and reserves and Apco is self-funding, no domestic capital is spent in Apco. Also with all the noise going on in Argentina, I'd like to stress that to our shareholders. But it does represent upside, particularly with the 250,000 net acres we have exposed to the Vaca Muerta Shale and Neuquen Basin. 
Slide 18. Our opinion on the recent Argentine government action that -- I think our opinion and the industry's opinion is that this dispute is between the Argentine government and Repsol, and it's not with the entire energy industry in Argentina. Apco has historically invested the majority of its earnings into exploration and development properties in Argentina, so we do not think it's any target towards Apco or any of the other companies, except there is a dispute between the Argentina government and Repsol. And again, I can't stress enough that we don't send any cash to Argentina. Apco is self-funding, less than 5% of our production and reserves. And we do believe, I think, we have attractive upside in the Vaca Muerta and Columbia. 
Speaking of that, if you look at Slide 19, first quarter operational update. We expect to increase our drilling investments in the Tordillo Formation, which is our traditional formation down there. We'll drill about 33 development wells in Argentina this year. And as you know, we continue to test the Coiron Amargo area for Vaca Muerta and we have 4 tests in the Coiron Amargo this year and one re-frac on the Bajada del Palo area. 
One of the wells is online, the CAS x-1 is -- there's been a press release by our partner. We continue to monitor that well. We intend to have other wells on later this year and the re-frac of the Bajada de Palo will also continue this year. So we'll continue to get more data points, as I mentioned, and understand what we have in Argentina and in the Vaca Muerta, in particular. 
And our first well in Colombia has reached the principal target, the Mirador Formation, and we are testing that well as we speak. And we will spud the second well in that area in the second quarter of 2012. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Rod Sailor for our financial results and 2012 guidance.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ralph. I'll turn you to Slide 21. This morning, we released our first quarter financial results, and I just want to touch on a couple of items. First, as mentioned, we have entered into an agreement to sell our Barnett, Arkoma assets. The numbe
componenttext:
Thank you, Ralph. I'll turn you to Slide 21. This morning, we released our first quarter financial results, and I just want to touch on a couple of items. First, as mentioned, we have entered into an agreement to sell our Barnett, Arkoma assets. The numbers represented both in our release and here have been adjusted to reflect the impact of that sale. 
The company's overall domestic, international production climbed 11% 1Q 2012 versus 1Q 2011, with average daily production of 1.4 Bcfe per day. For the quarter, that's slightly ahead of our expectations. Domestic gas was driven largely by increases in the Piceance and the Marcellus basins. Even with capital spending reductions, which -- that took effect late in the first quarter, we expect the Piceance production to continue to grow into the second quarter. We expect volumes to continue to rise in Marcellus as gas comes on from wells behind pipe and continued activity in Susquehanna County. Unfortunately, decade-low gas prices have impacted our gas revenues as realized prices are almost $1 lower first quarter 2012 versus first quarter 2011. 
Good news, oil -- total oil production is up 46% first quarter this year over first quarter last year. Our domestic oil production increases are driven by activities in our highest returning basin, the Bakken, whereas Ralph mentioned, we continue to be pleased with our well results. Oil production in the Bakken is up over 300%. We have seen basis differentials widen in the first quarter but -- and lower realized prices, but they were somewhat helped by higher oil prices in general. And as Ralph mentioned, we're taking steps to minimize basin differentials in the Bakken going forward. 
NGL productions was up 1Q 2012 versus 1Q 2011 as we continue to process more volumes, primarily in the Piceance basin. Quarter-over-quarter comparisons were helped somewhat by planned outages experienced in late first quarter 2011 on the fact that we're utilizing more firm interruptible capacity in first quarter 2012. Unfortunately, we continue to see a weakening in the price for composite barrel, which has impacted our realized prices in the first quarter of 2012.
As mentioned in our release, we have been experienced impairments totaling $52 million in the first quarter. Absent these impairments, our adjusted net loss from continuing operations would have been $9 million versus adjusted net income of $5 million in the first quarter 2011. Our adjusted EBITDAX totaled $262 million in the first quarter. Despite the realized gas prices being down approximately 20% lower than first quarter 2011, adjusted EBITDAX was only down approximately 6%, largely due to total production increases, especially higher volumes of oil and natural gas and hedges in place. 
At the bottom of Slide 21, again, total capital spending was $428 million for the first quarter. We announced our capital cuts in February. They started taking effect later in the first quarter. So on a go-forward basis, we do expect to see a continuing decrease for the remaining quarters in 2012. 
If I might turn you to Slide 22. We are adjusting our production and EBITDAX guidance to reflect the impact of the sale of our assets in the Barnett and Arkoma basins. This adjustment reduces our gas production to 1.09 Bcfe per day. It has no impact on our oil or natural gas liquids. EBITDAX guidance has been reduced by about $25 million to account for the loss of cash flow from the sale of our Barnett and Arkoma properties. 
And then down the middle of the page there, you can see no change for projected capital spending of $1.2 billion. We have broken out oil and NGLs on our rule of thumb metric to help in calculating price changes.
Finally, if I might turn you to Slide 23. Ralph just touched on this, but we have put a liquidity slide in the presentation. Good news is we have over $1.8 billion of liquidity. We expect to have no borrowings under our revolver at year end, and we expect to have the remainder of Arkoma and Barnett asset sale proceeds of approximately $75 million received here shortly. 
So before I turn it back over to Ralph, I'd just like to say, with strong production, continue to have a strong balance sheet and a low debt-to-EBITDA ratio. 
With that, I'll turn it back to Ralph.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rod. I'll sum it up with basically our premier portfolio. We have 18.5 Tcf of 3P reserves. Very strong balance sheet, as you can see our shift to oil [indiscernible] continues in the Bakken and the Piceance liquids recoveries. We are the #1 pro
componenttext:
Thank you, Rod. I'll sum it up with basically our premier portfolio. We have 18.5 Tcf of 3P reserves. Very strong balance sheet, as you can see our shift to oil [indiscernible] continues in the Bakken and the Piceance liquids recoveries. We are the #1 producer in Colorado. We are taking those efficiencies into the Bakken and the Marcellus. We expect to get better and better. We're very flexible on our capital budget as you've seen before. 
We're go to be very -- continue to have a strong balance sheet, which will be enhanced by the proceeds from the Barnett sale. And we like our 3 basins. We think those are the 3 best basis in the country. We like our financial strength. We're set up to survive very easily in this environment and to thrive as environment turns around. In the meantime, we'll continue to grow oil and liquids productions. 
So we feel very good about what we are. It's been a great -- I want to complement our employees on their first 100 days, how well they did and how everything has just come together very smoothly, and we're proud to have the opportunity to represent our WPX employees. 
With that, that's the end of prepared remarks. Dave?
