componenttext: Yes. Again, as we have talked about, we did renegotiate those contracts in 2011. On the processing side, we run about -- I think it's about $0.36. But then we also share proceeds of, I think, about 70% to 30%. So we are -- it's kind of percent of proceeds for the remainder. So I think -- so just -- I mean, when we put our plan and our guidance together, we were expecting to see a composite barrel of about $51 less about, I think, $6 deducts, $7 deducts to about $43 -- $45 -- sorry, $43. What we're seeing is a $43 composite barrel and a realized price of about $33 -- $33.15.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just in terms of, I guess, follow-on to that question. Could you talk about, I guess, the impact on your Piceance economics and does this change your view, I guess, heading into the back half of the year into 2013, if realizations continue

componenttextpreview: Well, actually -- this is Ralph. Our actual -- with the low gas prices -- well, the short answer is, no, it doesn't change it. We still are getting a nice uplift in the Piceance. We feel very comfortable with the 5 rigs we have operating there. And one of
componenttext: Well, actually -- this is Ralph. Our actual -- with the low gas prices -- well, the short answer is, no, it doesn't change it. We still are getting a nice uplift in the Piceance. We feel very comfortable with the 5 rigs we have operating there. And one of those is in the Ryan Gulch area, which is getting even more of an uplift, and it's more like 58 barrels per million. So we feel comfortable where we are with those 5 rigs [indiscernible].

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say while we're -- while we're all realizing less on our NGLs, the uplift is -- we still get a nice uplift because, again, the fuel and shrink piece is on the gas is so low. So we continue to meet our hurdle requirements in the Piceance even
componenttext: Yes, I would say while we're -- while we're all realizing less on our NGLs, the uplift is -- we still get a nice uplift because, again, the fuel and shrink piece is on the gas is so low. So we continue to meet our hurdle requirements in the Piceance even with the lower NGL realizations.

componenttextpreview: Great. And then just final question for me on the international side. In Colombia, would you be able to provide I guess the -- have you logged that well and would you be able to provide, I guess, the net pay that you saw in the Mirador? And then within th

Is this is an asset that you can potentially spin out over time to shareholders?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can you talk to us, is there any effort to add acreage outside of your 3 main areas in pursuing other forward-looking oil or liquids-focused projects?
componenttext: Can you talk to us, is there any effort to add acreage outside of your 3 main areas in pursuing other forward-looking oil or liquids-focused projects?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: We are very active looking in many areas. We always have been. Again, to do something, it's going to have to be very compelling. One of the areas I've mentioned many times on the road and in conferences that makes a lot of sense for us in addition to the
componenttext: We are very active looking in many areas. We always have been. Again, to do something, it's going to have to be very compelling. One of the areas I've mentioned many times on the road and in conferences that makes a lot of sense for us in addition to the current basin of the Bakken, if we could add there, is the wet window in the Utica shale. We think that would be a natural fit for our Marcellus team. We wouldn't have to add a new asset team. We could take our rigs and our dedicated completion crews interchangeably to the Utica from the Marcellus. In fact, the drilling and where they join in the Utica Shale right now is actually closer to our Canonsburg office than our Susquehanna drilling. So that's a natural fit for us. So we continue to look at that area. We understand it geologically. We think there are a number players there that might have more than that they can say grace over, that we might have an opportunity to maybe do some drill-to-earns with, and also some other producers that have not really -- not built to do large-scale efficiency type drilling like we do. So we might be able to get some opportunities that way. So that's an area that continues to have attraction to us. Again, it would have to be compelling to do anything there. And we also are -- I would say, the other major oil plays that you see in the nation, our technical team continues to scour, and our A&D and Land look at those. We have a good understanding of that. And if there was something compelling come along, we could also look at another basin.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as you look at the end of the year, your focused shifting towards oil, to anticipate some oil reserve adds, how do you guys think about proved undeveloped gas reserves and the potential revisions downward because of lower prices? Is it some
componenttext: Okay. And then as you look at the end of the year, your focused shifting towards oil, to anticipate some oil reserve adds, how do you guys think about proved undeveloped gas reserves and the potential revisions downward because of lower prices? Is it something you're already looking at?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, most of our portfolio has been very strong to low gas prices for many years. The one thing that we'll -- I think we'll have to look the most at is the 5-year rule in the large unconventional areas because it's really based on what your drilling prog
componenttext: Well, most of our portfolio has been very strong to low gas prices for many years. The one thing that we'll -- I think we'll have to look the most at is the 5-year rule in the large unconventional areas because it's really based on what your drilling program will be going forward. So those reserves don't really go away. But as you know, under the 5-year rule, take them off for a year and you add them for a year. So I would say that's one area that we will have a strong focus on. And I'm not saying anything is going to happen there, but that's traditionally what we'll have to look at. Neal, would you like to add anything to the reserve side?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I agree, Ralph. We have to demonstrate our plan to -- how much of these reserves to drill in the next 5 years will determine what's proved. But we also -- we always published our probable and possible reserves so they can have some movement back
componenttext: Yes. No, I agree, Ralph. We have to demonstrate our plan to -- how much of these reserves to drill in the next 5 years will determine what's proved. But we also -- we always published our probable and possible reserves so they can have some movement back and forth between the 2. And on the price case, the SEC encourages you to do alternate price scenarios as well. So typically, we'll do a case that's representative of what current prices are forward prices as well. So as Ralph said, I think a lot of that is just the technicalities of how you calculate under SEC rules. But we're not seeing anything that's a revision due to such things as poorer performance than expected or higher capital costs than expected.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think an important point on this is regarding our NGL position. We like to reemphasize this is that all of our product reaches Mont Belvieu. We're not exposed to large price differentials currently being experienced at Conway. So effectively, all o
componenttext: Yes, I think an important point on this is regarding our NGL position. We like to reemphasize this is that all of our product reaches Mont Belvieu. We're not exposed to large price differentials currently being experienced at Conway. So effectively, all of our products, either through Overland Pass Pipeline or Mid-American Pipeline, reaches Mont Belvieu.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Couple of quick questions in the Bakken. There was a question earlier about possible acquisitions elsewhere outside of your 3 main focus areas right now. I wanted to kind of drill in a little bit on the Bakken side of things. Are there many opportunities?
componenttext: Couple of quick questions in the Bakken. There was a question earlier about possible acquisitions elsewhere outside of your 3 main focus areas right now. I wanted to kind of drill in a little bit on the Bakken side of things. Are there many opportunities? Are you exploring any or seeing any opportunities to add significant pieces of acreage there in the Bakken for yourselves or is your, I guess, exploratory stuff going on in other places like the Utica?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: There are opportunities in the Bakken. I think people know we're interested. Again, we like what we have, approximately 90,000 acres. We have a lot of drilling ahead of us. We're gaining a lot of efficiencies. But we've made it known that we're interested
componenttext: There are opportunities in the Bakken. I think people know we're interested. Again, we like what we have, approximately 90,000 acres. We have a lot of drilling ahead of us. We're gaining a lot of efficiencies. But we've made it known that we're interested in the Bakken. We continue to like the Bakken, so there are opportunities in the Bakken. That's all I can say. Again, we do have a strong balance sheet, but we also are going to be very disciplined. So it'd have to be very compelling for us, but our deal team continuous to see opportunities.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can you add any color on those opportunities? What would you say -- especially in your area there near and around the reservation, is there kind of going rate for acreage costs in that portion of the Bakken?
componenttext: Can you add any color on those opportunities? What would you say -- especially in your area there near and around the reservation, is there kind of going rate for acreage costs in that portion of the Bakken?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: I mean, it seems to be all over the map right now, so not really. And I really can't add a lot more color. You're seeing some other deals that are published out there. You know what our original deal was. We like that deal, so that appears to be what some
componenttext: I mean, it seems to be all over the map right now, so not really. And I really can't add a lot more color. You're seeing some other deals that are published out there. You know what our original deal was. We like that deal, so that appears to be what some other acreage is going for. But I'm not predicting we're going to be at that level or anything like that. It's just that, I think, there's some areas just both on and off the reservations that are attractive to us. And all we can say is that we're interested, but we're not going to go jump out there and do anything that would strain our balance sheet.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then finally, in Bakken, you mentioned some cost improvements that you're seeing by leveraging all the work that you've done in the Piceance. Is there any change to maybe what our well cost assumptions should be right now or do you see a
componenttext: Okay, great. And then finally, in Bakken, you mentioned some cost improvements that you're seeing by leveraging all the work that you've done in the Piceance. Is there any change to maybe what our well cost assumptions should be right now or do you see a point in time, maybe it's the start of 2013, where those higher prices that we saw last quarter start to come down?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's still going to take some time. We're changing the whole fleet out, as we mentioned, by the third quarter. So that takes some time to get that done with the new rigs. We will move to pad drilling, and we hope to have those kinds of saving
componenttext: Yes, I think it's still going to take some time. We're changing the whole fleet out, as we mentioned, by the third quarter. So that takes some time to get that done with the new rigs. We will move to pad drilling, and we hope to have those kinds of savings. That's why we're going to pad drilling, but that's late third quarter. So I think that's really more of a look at 2013, maybe late 2012.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Robert Belinski with MorningStar.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Robert Belinski with MorningStar.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: I just had 2 quick questions. The first is how are you looking as far as inventory on Bakken permits and what are your expectations for that going forward, whether you can build inventory of permits or not? And then second, what is the incremental expecte
componenttext: I just had 2 quick questions. The first is how are you looking as far as inventory on Bakken permits and what are your expectations for that going forward, whether you can build inventory of permits or not? And then second, what is the incremental expected return that you anticipate from adding those ceramics to your completions in the Bakken?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Bryan. I'll take at least the first part of this. We continue to work aggressively on the permitting front. I think we are encouraged that some resources are being added on the regulatory side to better prosecute things in a timely fashion. We rep
componenttext: This is Bryan. I'll take at least the first part of this. We continue to work aggressively on the permitting front. I think we are encouraged that some resources are being added on the regulatory side to better prosecute things in a timely fashion. We reported last quarter that at least the prerequisite work that we're required to accomplish upfront, that is largely done for all of our pads. So what we're required to submit to initiate that permitting process has been completed on our side, very pleased with the effort around that over the past year. The logjam, of course, is over on the regulatory side. I think the good news is whenever we've had been in the pinch a little bit, we've been able to accelerate some things through that process, and so we have not had any idle time to date. We certainly would like to see that sieve open up a little bit. Currently, we've got about 2 -- I think 2 permits in front of each rig and so, perhaps, 60 to 90 days worth of lead time. Those aren't always the permits that you would like to have. But nonetheless, we've been able to stay out in front and avoid any standby time. We are expecting some breakthroughs very shortly just based on dialogues that we've had with the regulators there, the tribal involvement of late and the request, frankly, all the way to Secretary Salazar for additional resources to be plugged in to the process. So the short answer is, it's adequate but it could be better. We're doing okay though.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: And on the ceramic, I think, I appreciate that question. Using 65%, 35% ceramic sand mix adds about $1 million to our well cost versus the pure sand only. But if you just look at our chart that's on Slide 8, if you look at the best sand player that's on t
componenttext: And on the ceramic, I think, I appreciate that question. Using 65%, 35% ceramic sand mix adds about $1 million to our well cost versus the pure sand only. But if you just look at our chart that's on Slide 8, if you look at the best sand player that's on the reservation that we've compared to our reserves, we're 29% higher than and their reserves. If you look at worst, we're 94% better than a pure sand player. We also believe and it's our belief, and others may not believe this, that if you sand-only, that you're -- ultimately, the sand will get crushed and you have a lot more work-over costs and you ultimately spend more money on your well along down the life of the well versus the ceramics. So we're firmly convinced the 65%, 35% works. And our data shows that we're anywhere from 30% to 94% better than pure sand.

componenttext: Ralph, in these first calls, you're doing a very impressive job in a short time making an introduction of the company and covering results all at once, covering a lot of ground. On the HBP issues, you mentioned the Bakken is going to be done basically by the third quarter. Can you remind us where the Marcellus stands and is there anything else outstanding?

componenttext: The Marcellus is the only other place that's outstanding. With the 3 rigs operating, we will -- we could be in Susquehanna, have our production held by within about 18 to 24 months. Bryan, is that about right?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012

componenttext: Correct.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: And if we -- here's another way to look at it. If we did no drilling in Susquehanna, Westmoreland or Clearfield or Centre counties, over the next couple of years, meaning '13 and '14, we would -- we have the ability to -- if we wanted to, we could spend a
componenttext: And if we -- here's another way to look at it. If we did no drilling in Susquehanna, Westmoreland or Clearfield or Centre counties, over the next couple of years, meaning '13 and '14, we would -- we have the ability to -- if we wanted to, we could spend about $50 or so million could renew all of our leases based on the automatic kickers and things we have in there. So that would be the maximum exposure we have. And I would assume we didn't drill at all from now on. So we'll get it done within 12 to 18 months. And if prices were really poor, continue to be very, very poor, we could move those rigs and do other things and actually just renew our leases. And we like the areas. We would probably do that. But at this point, just on the drilling schedule, within 18 months or so.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've -- obviously, as you know, we haven't given out the '13 hedging philosophy but -- or our hedging position yet, but we are inclined to see -- generally, we'd like to have about, either on the gas/oil side -- it traditionally takes us about $800
componenttext: Yes, we've -- obviously, as you know, we haven't given out the '13 hedging philosophy but -- or our hedging position yet, but we are inclined to see -- generally, we'd like to have about, either on the gas/oil side -- it traditionally takes us about $800 million a year of CapEx to stay flat on our production, so to the extent we could hedge about half of our gas and traditionally we've done that. Obviously, we're not doing that now. But we like the oil prices we see out there, have seen this year for '13 and '14 -- or for 2013. So I would say that we would be willing to go up to about half hedged on oil at least. Rod, do you want to add to that?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I agree. We continue to see oil as attractive and will continue to look at hedging maybe a little farther out on oil. We're up in a touch on liquids. We're about 12% hedged on average for the remainder of this year on liquids, haven't talked abou
componenttext: Yes. No, I agree. We continue to see oil as attractive and will continue to look at hedging maybe a little farther out on oil. We're up in a touch on liquids. We're about 12% hedged on average for the remainder of this year on liquids, haven't talked about it. But again, it's really difficult to do liquids out much more than a year. But again, I would say looking at 2013, we'd like to be probably more aggressive on the hedging side on the oil and liquids side if we can continue to find attractive prices.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012

componenttext: Great. And there's a couple of questions about your NGL differentials and you all were commenting that the spread was really all off of the contractual positions for the most part because you were getting more Mont Belvieu pricing.  How long are those contracts out for?

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, those contracts are -- I think, they're about 10 years out. We believe that they're more life at least. What I neglected to add is, again, we think we will see some price improvement under those contracts in 2013. The fee will go from $0.36 to $0.07
componenttext: Well, those contracts are -- I think, they're about 10 years out. We believe that they're more life at least. What I neglected to add is, again, we think we will see some price improvement under those contracts in 2013. The fee will go from $0.36 to $0.07. We will -- or we will have a revenue sharing agreement at 50-50 on margin up to $0.34. And then after anything over $0.34, we will keep 80% of the margins. So I would say our composite barrel right now is about 60% ethane and 19% propane. We've seen those prices significantly weaken from the fourth quarter of last year. That's impacting it. And then again, we'll see some fee improvement in 2013 as these -- the impact of these renegotiated contracts come into play.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can just add on the ethane side. This is Mike Fiser. The second half of the year does look better than what we saw than first quarter on ethane, in particular. Some of those crackers are back online in the second and third quarter. That will help d
componenttext: Yes, I can just add on the ethane side. This is Mike Fiser. The second half of the year does look better than what we saw than first quarter on ethane, in particular. Some of those crackers are back online in the second and third quarter. That will help dramatically. Overall, supply, demand for ethane is fairly balanced through the end of '12. We're adding about 95,000 barrels of petchem [petrochemical] demand, and the fractionation increases are about the same. So we see supply, demand on ethane fairly balanced into the first part of '13. So we're optimistic that we could be under a little better price environment for ethane through balance of the year.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everybody. Welcome to the WPX Energy Second Quarter 2012 Operational Update. We appreciate your interest in WPX Energy.  Ralph Hill, our CEO; and Rod Sailor, our CFO, will review the prepared slide presentation this morning. [Tech
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everybody. Welcome to the WPX Energy Second Quarter 2012 Operational Update. We appreciate your interest in WPX Energy.  Ralph Hill, our CEO; and Rod Sailor, our CFO, will review the prepared slide presentation this morning. [Technical Difficulty] Rod Sailor, members of the senior management team, Brian Guderian, Senior VP of Operations; Neal Buck, Senior VP of A&D and Land; and Mike Fiser, Senior VP of Marketing, will be available for questions after the presentation.
This morning on our website, wpxenergy.com, you'll find today's presentation and the press release that was issued earlier today. The second quarter Q will be filed later this week, and you'll be able to access that on the website as well.  Please review the forward-looking statements on Slide 2 and the disclaimer on the oil and gas reserves on Slide #3. They're important and intrical to our remarks, so please review them.
Also included are various non-GAAP numbers that have been reconciled back to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. Those schedules follow the presentation. So with that, Ralph, I'll turn it over to you.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David Slide 1. First, welcome to our second quarter 2012 earnings call, and thank you for your interest in WPX. A few reminders about WPX. We do have a premier portfolio and we've had some very strong production growth in all 3 product lines, w
componenttext:
Thank you, David Slide 1. First, welcome to our second quarter 2012 earnings call, and thank you for your interest in WPX. A few reminders about WPX. We do have a premier portfolio and we've had some very strong production growth in all 3 product lines, with our oil production up 57% versus last year, our liquids production up 10% and our gas production also grew up 8 -- grew 8%. And when the commodity environments we can increase our gas volume production growth quite a bit and go back in the double-digit gas production growth. 
Our existing portfolio 18.5 3 TCF [sic] reserves disability to go all 3 product lines without any new investments for many years in the future. We're choosing not to go gas as much as we could right now due to low commodity environment. We continue to have tremendous flexibility in our capital spending up or down without losing our leases. As you've seen earlier this year, we significantly decreased our capital budget. We are a technical and low-cost leader. Our balance sheet remains very strong, particularly compared to our peers with about $1.9 billion liquidity. This gives us a position of strength to grow in our core areas and also new areas as we see compelling opportunity and we're very excited to say that we've entered some new areas. We don't have a lot of detail we can give you on that, but we increased our capital primarily because of our opportunities we see through our exploration team to grow in horizontal oil plays, new plays. 
It's part of our natural progression as ANP company, a stand-alone company to enter new oil plays much earlier and we're excited about that. 
By choice and design, we think we are in the best oil basin ini the nation in the Bakken, the best gas and liquid basin in Piceance and really exclusively to WPX, but we are exclusively the best in the Piceance, and we are the best gas basin in the nation in Marcellus. 
Let's flip to Slide 3 or 4 please. Same quarter highlights. Our employees are focused on what they control, and so are we, which is our production growth and our cost. And so we can't control such as the commodity prices currently are weak, international domestic economies. Thus, we'er focusing in our plan, which is our production side and our cost side. And I'm very pleased to report, we're executing on that plan with our combined year-to-date oil and gas -- oil and liquids production up 24%. 
As I mentioned, domestic gas is up 8%, and the Piceance is still receiving in what is a weak NGL margin of 66% per Mcf uplifts. So even a very weak NGL market, we're getting quite a bit of uplift in the Piceance. 
Looking solely at the Bakken, our production in oil was up 83%, quite an achievement, and our cost returning lower, our LOEs down 6% and our combined basis on gathering, processing and transportation costs are down 10%.  
Our EBITDAX is over $500 million for 6 months. And as mentioned as Ronald talked about, we continue to have superior liquidity compared to our peers with over $1.9 billion in liquidity side. And we're now deploying additional capital in new oil-focused plays, which we are very excited to do as a team.
Slide 5. Just very quickly. Reminder, the Bakken we think is a world-class oil basin and our results continue to show as we expected through our exploration team, which is also the team that's leading us to these new plays that were located in the best remaining undeveloped reservoir in the Bakken play. 
Slide 6. We're pleased with this reservoir and our performance so far, with early time well results well above our acquisition thesis and confirming again that we're in the best part of the play. 
For July -- for June 12, our net barrels production a day was $11,300 barrels a day approximately, which is a 74% increase over June of 2011. Our performance is improving.
4 of our 6 drilling rigs have been converted to new efficency rigs and 2 more are in the transit. We have our dedicated frac crews in place and are reducing time and cost. But as you've heard from other operators, and you've seen in our capital increase today, there's substantial upward pressure on cost to the first quarter of this year, which continued in the second quarter, but we feel they have peaked in the second quarter. 
Based on our experience today, part of our capital increase 75 million is for additional drilling completion of facility cost in the Bakken. 
There's unique issues driving our performance and strategy that we feel will go away, but there's a new operator, just taken over operations slightly over a year ago. It takes a while to become an established operator in this basin. 
So for the first 3 quarters, what we've been facing is basically saving mode. Since we've ceased operations a year ago, we've been transitioning to much -- we will transition to much more efficient pad drilling. But initially, we've been bouncing around from lease to lease to make sure we hold our leases. 
The good news is we only have 10 wells to drill and have all leases held by production and all those wells -- or majority of those wells will be clean completely by the end of third quarter and definitely this year. 
For the 2013, thus the majority of our drilling will be from pads and we'll be done with the long rig moves, we'll be done with doing initial roads, infrastructure pads, production facilities, et cetera, all that will go away. And we build our of preferred vendors, contracts and equipment to where we like for Piceance-type efficiency model. 
We believe we're now at the front of the Q or near the front of the Q from services from our vendors. We can optimize our service equipment. I've mentioned
4 of our 6 rigs are now fit for purpose rigs, but 2 of those just recently came on. So we have not experienced of those yet. We've high-graded our directional drilling services. We've got our completions and operation efficiencies underway, and we've optimized our completion design. 
We also put in field infrastructure, the one I talked about last time, the Van Hook Fields construction will be done in the fourth quarter, and that will eliminate flaring, trucking of our oil and, water and among other things, and thus same more money. 
So we expect as we get done with the one-and-gone lease saving development phase later this year, that we'll be able to lower our well cost by about $2 million. 
Also you should see that we do by operating on the reservation, just generally person, associated fees and other items. There's about a $500,000 per well additional cost by operating the reservation. The good news is the reservoirs are superior. And we use and believe in 65% ceramic and 35% profit mix. That adds about $1 million to our wells. But the slide, I'll show you in a few minutes. We believe that results in superior wells and superior production and superior reserves and eliminates any problems down the road when the sand could get crushed to be using 100% sand.
Slide 7. 4 of the 6 planned rigs have been converted to new fit for purpose. And as I mentioned, just a couple of those have been delivered. So we really have not began that efficiency-type drilling. As I mentioned, that will happen later in the third quarter, beginning the fourth quarter. But our reserves in production continued grabs in our expectations. 
Despite the busy slide, but let me walk you through a couple of things. 11 wells -- we spent 11 wells in the second quarter. And you can see the light green and the orage, the colors there, we put 6 wells on first sales. We're drilling from a first multi-well pad and project has begun, but we're doing for the lock in Three Forks and that's in the red hash marks on the map. 
Our best well result from -- during pad drilling has gone down to 25 days. Averaging 30 days right now, but we already start to achieve 25 days, gives me confidence will drive our well cost. 
We delineated our field or we continue to delineate our field and we proofed up some assets in the south. Our first completion was much higher than we expected. Our peak months was 1,039 barrels of oil a day versus our plan of 700 barrels or less, so we're very encouraged about the 7 part. 
Currently, we're stepping out to the West to lineate  the acreage there, and we have -- we should have results on those in the third quarter report. And we're improving up our Three Forks formation. 4 wells are waiting on completion, but we do have 2 that are on and flying better than we thought with higher EURs and we expected. So we continue to see good opportunities or good results from our drilling here. And really, we've been drilling with older equipment, with not the frac crews we wanted and many other services. So as we move to what we call the Piceance, we'll think we'll do much better. 
Slide 8. We believe that our Anchorage and our use of 65% ceramic and 35% sand as our profit provide superior results and peers, only that some of our peers use. 
This does add about $1 million cost, as I mentioned. But if you look at the performance here, our performance for the wells easily offsets the additional cost. You can see on a 180-day rate, the WPX is superior to all the other operators out there. And this is a substantial about 85% of activity on the reservation. 
You can also see that our EUR comparison is higher and that is on NBO basis to 640 and if you create that to an NBOE basis, it's 706, which is not curve do you see previous-type curves. That also is includes in our piece some delineation wells to the south, some Three Forks wells and delineation we're beginning to the West and the East. So as we stay more in a sweet spot, really that will trend up. These are all wells that are completed on the Indian reservation. We're all Middle Bakken long laterals and we believe 180-day rate and this is calculated by third party, IHS data public, it's public data. So this is all public that you can go out there and see that are wells are doing better than our peers. 
Also, we believe the 180-day rate is a much superior rate to look at versus just the 24-hour IP. Slide 8 -- Slide 9. In the first quarter, our WTI discount was about 16%, WTI. Second quarter that's decrease to about 12% to 14%. 
And also on absolute basis, artificially improve by $4 per barrel. We expect this will improve as the year goes on by $2 for the balanced year for basin of 10% to $11. 
As we see our Van Hook Gathering System completed, we think on the Van Hook barrels, that will save us additional $4 and that should be completed by the  fourth quarter. We also continue to make progress in our rails agreement as we talked about last time. it's still on fly where we think for the 2013 to 2015 period, we'll be up to 20,000 barrels of oil,  we can move on the rail. 
Turning to Piceance Slide 10. It is a world-class gas and oil. An NGO plya and it is for us. Some others don't have the position we had. But our geologic position is unique, relative to other operators and we're the only operator scale to be efficient. We drilled over 4,000 wells, we have 10,000 remaining locations, we have the lowest structure. I'ts by our technology and our operational, coupled with our enhanced liquids processing. 
And superior liquid contract sales, as you'll see in our barrels. Net realized barrels and we'er unique and I do believe as the prices turn the WPX is in a unique position to which our gas production, particularly in the Piceance. 
Slide 11. Update on the second quarter. We did spent 53 wells, 123 wells to the second quarter per year-to-date. We've had a record gross operating production of almost $950 million a day. Higher volumes and a stronger NGL uplift of with.66 per Mcf, in that second quarter and that was despite the vary weak price that you these out there. 
We continue to gain efficiencies, with your slide will show you. Show even in the Highlands, and we're not really drilling much in the Highlands, but area, we've developed simultaneous operations, which as you know, we've been in a valley where we drill complete, produced stimulate on the same path at the same time. We've glenn the Highlands for the first time, leverage the value efficiencies that we have. And we actually have done a Iran Goltzwell in a record day, driling up 8.5 days and the average Ryan Gulch wells are now taking revenue 11 to 12 base, that was about 25 days 3 years ago. So it's a signifcant there in the improvement there in the wrangeled area. And a good opportunity for us is when you begin to deliver in a much larger scale. We also have new valley recognition projects in the mangoes in Niobrara. Third party results are very encouraging. I have another slide on this, in our opportunities later. But there've about 27 horizontal wells drilled by other operators. So far, our first horizontal wells will spread this month or next month and have hopefully completion by the end of the year. So we're excited about that as we move forward and I'll talk about this again in a few minutes. 
Slide 12. The efficiencies continue year after year after year. In the Piceance, we continue to set drilling records. It's a relentless drive this team has for efficiency and our value well cost have actually been flat the last couple of years. 
When as you know, there's inconsiderable upside pressure in all basins we have been managed to efficiencies to keep our costs flat or slightly down. It's done by our performance in optimization and from active vendor negotiations, and also great vendors that we have. 
We're forecasting our Ryan Gulch wells are not going to move less than $3 million. And I mentioned how much the drilling time has come down, so it should be substantially below that. 
We have a continuous reduction in spud-to-spud times and every time you save a day up in the Piceance, you're saving $40,000 to $60,000. Our low-end rig count actually had a side benefit of allowing us to lower our average day rate for our fleet and prepare us for efficient ramp up, and we've done many other things to optimize as the team always does. 
Slide 13. If you look at our weighted average barrel, it was $36.27 in the second quarter. Even with historically low ethane and propane prices in the same quarter, I mentioned the $0.66 per Mcf uplift. If the new Willow Creek deal or if the Willow Creek new contract, which kicks in automatically in 2013, was in place in the second quarter, that uplift who have been 70 -- $0.72. So even in one of the worst environments have been out there for ethane in quite awhile, if you annualize that on a fourth quarter basis, that would have been about $16 million improvement to EBITDAX for the year. And we believe, going forward, as we mentioned before, that we think that's going to be more like $25 million to $35 million improvement in the future. 
We feel we're in good position to continue to realize significant valuable from our NGLs based on our advantage long-term T&F rates, and all of our products, more importantly, offprice and not subject to Conway. 
Slide 14. Since our last call on May 3, gas prices have come up somewhat, about 7%. On calendar '13, it's $3.73, and I believe and our team believes that we are one of the best positioned companies to respond to the coming opportunity to rapidly deploy rigs, an increased production when gas prices recover. 
We believe that the Piceance size rigs will be available versus rigs that are going to be needed for the longer drilling horizontal gas shale plays. You can see on this graph, we've done it before. We have about 30% -- 31% CAGR growth rate in the Piceance for 2004 and 2008, and as you can see, we increased our BCF production by about 157 BCF from '04 to '08. 
We're at so much more efficient now. We can drill, do the same kind of growth with only 17 rigs versus 26 rigs the last time we did it, and we're given example here if we start off with a 8 rigs and you want to move up, 17 rigs. That would be up 12% CAGR for the Piceance we can do and the total production growth of about 155 BCF. Really, same amount of production growth. We believe that we have that in place and can take advantage of that. We believe we can get the rigs. We have well over 200 permits in hand and ready to drill. 
Our infrastructure, as you know, is in place. The capacity to move the gas north, south, west is in plays. Our staff has done up to 27 rigs before, so they can easily handle 17 rigs. The support structure is there. We have the lowest drilling completion and operating cost from the basin and we can wrap up sooner. We think that anybody else can in other basin. We can utilize available rigs. As I mentioned, I believe the Piceance size rigs would be available and we can build off to smart knowledge from our prior ramp up. 
So due to our people, our knowledge, our experience our low cost of operations, our low development costs and our infrastructure already built out. We are one of the best gas storage just waiting to explode when the prices are right. 
Our final basin is the Marcellus is Slide 15. As I mentioned before, our technical team which is leading us to the new areas. We increased our capital 4. Also purposely got in this primarily for Susquehanna County part of Marcellus. We like what we've seen in Marcellus. We continue to have great results. We also believe the team has cracked the code on lower drilling completion costs and the Piceance model inefficiency is starting to kick in, and it's actually kicking in there. We do remain frustrated with the operations of the laser pipeline in terms of reliability and pressure. But we believe our former sister company, WPZ, which acquired the system in February will bring the system at the par and hopefully by the end of this year, early next year. 
Slide 16. As I mentioned, the Piceance model is taking hold in Marcellus. We have transition to new rigs both specifically for Pennsylvania on track to average 3 rigs this year. Our first Ryan, Rick came in as planned at the end of May.  2 hours are scheduled to come in later this year, the end of this month and the 1st of November. We've reduced our completion cost. It has been a major focus for us and they're down 30% from last year, a significant progress made, Our net production increased 19% from the first quarter to the second quarter, actual at June. 
We believe that production continues to be impacted by very highlighting pressures and erratic operational performance by laser, which the pressures have been running between 600 pounds to 800 pounds. We do estimate our current net production of $70 million a day, could have been about $30 million a day higher, absent any infrastructure constraints. If we can see the problems we continue to have there. And we are poised to ramp up quickly when the gas price rebound.  Not as quickly as of the us, but Marcellus would be in pretty good shape. 
Slide 17. I'm looking at the efficiency model, how you see this. This was almost a mirror of what we saw starting with the Piceance and the Piceance continues to do a spread of rig release time has continued drop and average an all-time low about 16 days in the second quarter. Early in the play this was a closure to 30 days, so great improvement by the team. The 60% improvement from where we started just 2 years ago. 
As I mentioned, completion costs have been reduced to operational changes, better frac designs and working with our vendors and getting more partnerships them. We're down about 20% on average since the beginning of the year. And Marcellus just looks like an absolute great example WPX transporting to P&L model to the Marcellus and we believe this will start to occur and begin to occur in the Bakken as they crack the code also. 
Slide 18, let's look internationally briefly. As you know, we owned 600 interest in Altco.
I do want to stress and continue to stress that APCO represents less than 5% of our total production reserves and. No domestic capital spin on 
APCO. Also on the upside, we do have about 250,000 exposed to the Bakken Shale. there was a government distress this week.
Now the car require an annual approval oil and gas company's investment plan. Here's our thoughts on than, early thoughts, we've invested consistently and significantly develop our holdings over the year. We basically redeploy our cash down there into reinvestment. We need to see the detailed requirements from process yet to be published by government. It appears the degree is to formalize rules that the government is already posing on the industries, which some of those are like flash controls. It seems this is move by the government for tigther controls, and involvement with the country's energy resources. But I mentioned we've always, we've always redeployed our capital down there, internally, not the domestic capital.
We have investment programs built into our concession agreements already. So we have that already set up. and few of these are still being approved as the concessions remain extended. So we hope that we -- that what we have in place already is very satisfactory to the new government rules, and time will tell on that.
Looking at our operational update, for all of 2012, we're going to do 33 development wells and 5 exploration wells and these are in the traditional targets at Tordillo and formations. Production-site from results in this area have been in line with expectations. As you know, we have 2 wells on production, the Bakken more and the vertical side. Current plans already call for a multistage fracs of the CAS x-4 before the end of the year. So we continue to prosecute and understand what we have in the Bakken between what we're doing and what the industry is doing. 
In Colombia, we annouced our first discovery and it allows 32 blocks, where we currently had a 20% working unit. Interest 1 well. That is on production, as average about 2,400 barrels of oil a day since July. Our second well has found prospect paid in 3 formations and the casing has been set. Completion rig is in location and it will commence testing of these formations. And 440, we've also completed our seismic specs and drilling there in 2013. So we continue to do good in the operational side on the Atco. 
Slide 20. We are excited to discuss a couple of existing future opportunities in our early entry in our promising new play. As I mentioned, as pure coming we are diversifying our strategy to use exploration and land earlier and get into plays earlier. For more economically, we think this will be a nice balance to the traditional A&D work we have done. opportunities that ultimately come through this year, we'll represent about 60% to 65% of the $200 million capital increase.
Slide 21. First, let me remind you that an existing resource we control in the Piceance base and we made it significant side and what's called the gas formation. We own 250,000 drills, about 150,000 net acres. If you look at the opposite operators and the number of things going on out there, that could represent 20 to 32 TCF of unplug resource potential based on results of other operators of 67 bcf a well. Our current activity is we had an initial vertical test on last year and we frac one zone and uploaded $1 million per day. We have 5 to 7 additional in the remaining to be tested and that and as I mentioned, our first quarter horizontal well is planned for the third quarter of this year and it's going to be offset to that vertical stage. Too that vertical well. Other operators have drilled or spread 27 wells in this area, all horizontal typos, with additional 65 locations per minute. And again, the wells are being reported 67 Bcf range. None of this business is in our resource potential, our currently resource potential 18.5 Tcf of 3 TCF of 3 P reserve. Or and what I mention is that what we currently have in the Piceance of 10,000 remaining locations. So this represents significant gas upside to us when the time would be right and we hold it by production, we can develop when we want to. 
Slide 22. We also made a Mancos gas discovery inthe San Juan basin, were we lead the charges and made the discovery. We did number of vertical cast in the Mancos, extends it reservoir and geological assessments. Basically, the bottom line is we drilled 2 gas horizontal Mancos wells, the first one looks like it's going to be between 4.5 to 5.5 BCF, the second one between 5 to 6 BCF. We control a substantial amount of Mancos rights held by production of 61,000 acres. Have a number of 700 locations. On a gross basis, it looks like we have a 3 Tcf of gross exposure, which should be about 1.8 Tcf to us. Again, none of these numbers are in our resource potential. We look to prosecute this at the time and the San Juan basin team has been drilling there from a number years. So that's a right time, at the good upside for us. 
Finally, we did enter -- we are entering or have entered new oil plays, 3 or 4 primary areas of interest to us. All of these are oil focus towards horizontal plays. We're very, very good of our positions, we like what we've done. Our capital budget by a $100 million, and that could go up even a little bit more, but not much, it wouldn't change guidance. 
We will begin testing this year, most of those wells will be vertical test. Initial well results are expected no later than mid 2013. Obviously, we have increased capital today and we did not increase production guidance, but it's not prudenterprise to increase production guidance on exploration time, but we're very excited where we are and where we ahead with these prospects and I think it's to going to see. Part of WPX you haven't seen before is our exploration and land team have got this in the right place in a more mature, these earlier entries in the places that aren't mature, but we think they're going to do pretty well. With that I'll turn it over to Rod.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ralph. Slide 25. Earlier this morning, we released our second quarter results. These results reflected weak gas prices. And even with the impact from our hedge position, we realized approximately $3 per Mcf. As well we continue to see weakening
componenttext:
Thank you, Ralph. Slide 25. Earlier this morning, we released our second quarter results. These results reflected weak gas prices. And even with the impact from our hedge position, we realized approximately $3 per Mcf. As well we continue to see weakening in the price of our composite NGL barrel. Further impacting results worldwide basin differentials in the Bakken in the month of April. And while the differential somewhat normalized by June, the price accrued also retreated as so your net not much changed in the realized price over the quarter. We are still on plan to be meet our volume projections and currently looking very favorable in our outlook for oil and NGLs. Results were also impacted by non-cash impairments probables in the Powder River basin total approximately $65 million for the quarter, until impairments year-to-date of $117 million. 
Adjusting out these and unrealized mark-to-market gains tripled to our hedging program, we experienced an adjusted net loss from operations for the quarter of $30 million and $37 million year-to-date. 
Even in this challenging commodity environment, we had just over $0.25 billion in adjusted EBITDAX and $514 million year-to-date adjusted EBITDAX. 
Ralph previously mentioned, and while it is mentioned capital increases and while it is running ahead of previous estimates, we believe we are touring the corner on our cost in the Bakken and have may and will continue to make additional land purchases. 
Turning to Slide 26. That now brings us to our outlook for the year. While we did see significant pressure on prices in the second quarter, we are seeing gas strengthening, ethane propane prices are stronger, are looking stronger and should benefit us in the third quarter. 
As I indicated, we continue to feel good about our full-year production estimates. EBITDAX estimates are within our sensitivities and based on 7 31 script prices with what we realized to date, we would anticipate that our adjusted EBITDAX would probably be $85 million to $100 million lower than the original $1,175,000,000. 
As previously mentioned, we re increasing our capital expenditures estimate by approximately $200 million and this is related to the costs in the Bakken and some target anchorage acquisition that Ralph had mentioned. 
Turning to Slide 27. Second quarter liquidity remained strong. While we are seeing a higher spending and some pressure on cash flow for the low commodity prices, these were more than offset by the $300 million we received from the sale of our Barnett and Arkoma properties in the second quarter. Liquidity at the end of the quarter stood at approximately $1.9 billion. And again, as Ralph mentioned, we think we're positioned very well from a liquidity and a balance sheet standpoint as we ended the second quarter. 
And with that, I will turn it back over to Ralph to wrap up.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rod. Slide 28. So remaining priorities for 2012 in our value creation. We've already continue to do this, we continue to grow our domestic oil production, 50% to 60%. As I mentioned first 6 months is up 57%. We are uniquely situated to ramp up
componenttext:
Thank you, Rod. Slide 28. So remaining priorities for 2012 in our value creation. We've already continue to do this, we continue to grow our domestic oil production, 50% to 60%. As I mentioned first 6 months is up 57%. We are uniquely situated to ramp up gas production at the right price. We already one of the most efficient producers and we are seeing our gas cost basins trend lower. 
The Piceance deficiency is continuing to be best-in-class and the Marcellus team has cracked the efficiency growth. And I'd discussed, I really can't stress it out, when the time is right I believe and we believe, particularly in the Piceance, we can significantly grow our gas production as that one slide showed you how much we can do with less equivalent than we did in the past. 
We are going to maintain our top-tier balance sheet in this depressed environment, but the environment is getting a little bit better. As we continue to execute financial discipline in the Bakken, we expect several things happen. All of our acreage will be held by production. That is a great thing. We will have all fit-for-purpose rigs designed for the Bakken operation. 4 in now, 2 that recently came on, 2 more coming, they're all 6 will be there. We should begin pad drilling in the third quarter which should lower well cost ultimately by $2 million as efficiencies kick in. 
We'll complete our final gathering system for all of our oil and water and gas and none of that will have to be trucked. And in the future, we could probably and I believe we will be able to drill the same number of wells with one less rig. In other way was these rigs could be drilled -- the same amount of wells drill 5 rigs in the future sees efficiencies began to kick out, and that will make us.  When we do have rigs, we'll go to dig that there are more wells. And our new opportunities there in the Piceance, we're going to spread our Mancos horitizontal to just for gas to continue to evaluate this potential large gas. We're also continuing to maximize the liquids recovery. I did dimension the Powder River, but we are evaluating numerous oil prospects where we 140,000 acres of the price. We'll begin to participate in some of these prospects, continue to test our Argentina where we have 250,000 acres as I mentioned. And we'll begin testing the new exploration oil areas where we've investment approximately $100 million. We believe those things will -- as we do some vertical test and have some results early next year, hopefully, you'll be pleased with those results. And finally we'll continue to tell the WPX story that we have of our disciplined management team, our great balance sheet, our tremendous opportunities that the hold in-house today and our new oral -- horizontal expiration properties. Thank you for your interest in WPX and with that, I'll turn it to David.

componenttext:
Well I'll start in now let Bryan. We cut $2 million now instead, We Basically drilling 45 wells in the Bakken this year so if you look at the $60 million, we wanted about $10.5 well cost this year and with $75 million increase, the way that translate that to the network and interest, that's about a $12.5 million wells that have. So we believe we can get down to $10.5 million, that's with the pad drilling and better completions and I'll let brian take over there for the. Why won't you answer the last part of that. But we should be able to drive it down to $10.5. Certainly, we're not happy where costs are at this point in time. Either I think you've seen some color around this perhaps from the other companies that have already released. 
We have drilled since we bought into the project about 45 wells, we have what we would consider to be I guess near final cost on about 30. Looking at the drivers of those actual cost versus what we've been targeting. As Ralph said, $10.5 million. I guess there's one area that we haven't really talk about that I would add a little color to. We feel like there's Ralph has mentioned the $2 million savings when we transitioned the pad drilling. Frankly, we feel like there's a couple of million dollars worth of savings associated with improving our contractor and vendor service quality of the wells that we drilled. Thus bar, there's still a lot of problems associated with executing on those wells, and I think it's generally driven by the demand for services in the Bakken. The services and the experience of those folks just have been running hard to catch up to the operator demand that exist in the basin. We seen pretty significant improvement on all fronts with respect to our rigs, our dedicated frac crew. And so again, we still believe that over time, as we get the pad drilling, as we take the problem wells out, which are fairly common early and aggressive growth basin like this, that we can take $2 to $2.5 million off of our current run rate. Ralph mentioned we're looking at $12.5 million as our estimate for well cost over the balance of this year, and we hope to drive that considerably lower as we get into pad drilling, which will be the prevailing mode of operation for us in 2013.

headline: WPX Energy, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Bryan. I'll take the question. My answer is probably the same as it was last quarter it remains continuous. We've like to see things move at a much faster cliff. But at least up to this point, it's been managaela. We haven't had any rig idle time
componenttext: This is Bryan. I'll take the question. My answer is probably the same as it was last quarter it remains continuous. We've like to see things move at a much faster cliff. But at least up to this point, it's been managaela. We haven't had any rig idle time as a result of waiting on permits. Last, I think it was early in the year and into the maybe even the second quarter, the BLM form, a kind of permitting task force that was assisted and I think even partially funded by industry. And so they cleared the pretty significant backlog. As a part of that process, we got some 25 or 30 in essentially a very short timeframe, which gave us a nice inventory to stay in front of the rigs. But I think you've probably heard from some of the other operators since the task force went away, things to have slowed down again. On our side, we created about office that packed this issue with the first bought into the basin and so the good news for us is very vast majority of our prerequisite work is on has already been completed and so our permits are actually sitting in the pipeline either at the BLM or at the FDIC and so the short answer is it remains continuous review is manageable we've done our part our work is largely completed and up least up to this point in time, when things get tight we've been able to push things through the systems are currently we've got a couple of permits out in front of each of our rigs. So we'd would like to see it improve, but it has manageable up to this point.
